events.title: Tom's Evasion and Aunt Polly's Jam Discovery
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly repeatedly calls for Tom but receives no answer.
She searches the room, using her spectacles more for appearance than for sight, as they are her 'state pair'.
Muttering a threat, she pokes under the bed with a broom, only managing to disturb the cat.
She then goes to the open door, scans the garden, and calls for Tom again, projecting her voice.
A slight noise behind her alerts her, and she turns to catch Tom attempting to sneak away from a closet.
Aunt Polly questions Tom about his activities in the closet and notices jam on his hands and mouth.
She reminds Tom of her repeated warnings about the jam and declares her intention to punish him with a switch.
As the switch is about to be used, Tom cleverly diverts Aunt Polly's attention by exclaiming about something behind her.
While Aunt Polly is distracted, Tom seizes the moment to escape by climbing over a high board-fence.

segmentation_boundaries.first_sentence: “Tom!”
segmentation_boundaries.last_sentence: The lad fled on the instant, scrambled up the high board-fence, and disappeared over it.

events.text_segment:
“Tom!”
No answer.
“TOM!”
No answer.
“What’s gone with that boy,  I wonder? You TOM!”
No answer.
The old lady pulled her spectacles down and looked over them about the room; then she put them up and looked out under them. She seldom or never looked through them for so small a thing as a boy; they were her state pair, the pride of her heart, and were built for “style,” not service—she could have seen through a pair of stove-lids just as well. She looked perplexed for a moment, and then said, not fiercely, but still loud enough for the furniture to hear:
“Well, I lay if I get hold of you I’ll—”
She did not finish, for by this time she was bending down and punching under the bed with the broom, and so she needed breath to punctuate the punches with. She resurrected nothing but the cat.
“I never did see the beat of that boy!”
She went to the open door and stood in it and looked out among the tomato vines and “jimpson” weeds that constituted the garden. No Tom. So she lifted up her voice at an angle calculated for distance and shouted:
“Y-o-u-u TOM!”
There was a slight noise behind her and she turned just in time to seize a small boy by the slack of his roundabout and arrest his flight.
“There! I might ’a’ thought of that closet. What you been doing in there?”
“Nothing.”
“Nothing! Look at your hands. And look at your mouth. What is that truck?”
“I don’t know, aunt.”
“Well, I know. It’s jam—that’s what it is. Forty times I’ve said if you didn’t let that jam alone I’d skin you. Hand me that switch.”
The switch hovered in the air—the peril was desperate—
“My! Look behind you, aunt!”
The old lady whirled round, and snatched her skirts out of danger. The lad fled on the instant, scrambled up the high board-fence, and disappeared over it.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Dilemma and Resolve
detailed_summary: Aunt Polly, initially surprised by Tom's escape, chuckles at his cleverness.
She reflects on her inability to anticipate Tom's recurring tricks, calling herself an 'old fool'.
She acknowledges Tom's knack for knowing how far he can push her and his ability to diffuse her anger with distractions or by making her laugh, thereby avoiding punishment.
She expresses guilt over her leniency, believing she is failing in her duty to discipline him properly, citing the proverb 'Spare the rod and spile the child'.
Aunt Polly recognizes Tom's inherent mischief but admits her deep affection for him as her late sister's son makes it difficult for her to be stern.
She describes her internal conflict: her conscience troubles her when she spares him, and her heart aches when she punishes him.
She resigns herself to the troubles of life and anticipates Tom will play hooky that afternoon.
She resolves to make Tom work on Saturday as a consequence, acknowledging it's a difficult but necessary measure given his strong aversion to work, to prevent his 'ruination'.

events.text_segment:
His aunt Polly stood surprised a moment, and then broke into a gentle laugh.
"Hang the boy, can’t I never learn anything? Ain’t he played me tricks enough like that for me to be looking out for him by this time? But old fools is the biggest fools there is. Can’t learn an old dog new tricks, as the saying is. But my goodness, he never plays them alike, two days, and how is a body to know what’s coming? He ’pears to know just how long he can torment me before I get my dander up, and he knows if he can make out to put me off for a minute or make me laugh, it’s all down again and I can’t hit him a lick. I ain’t doing my duty by that boy, and that’s the Lord’s truth, goodness knows. Spare the rod and spile the child, as the Good Book says. I’m a laying up sin and suffering for us both, I know. He’s full of the Old Scratch, but laws-a-me! he’s my own dead sister’s boy, poor thing, and I ain’t got the heart to lash him, somehow. Every time I let him off, my conscience does hurt me so, and every time I hit him my old heart most breaks. Well-a-well, man that is born of woman is of few days and full of trouble, as the Scripture says, and I reckon it’s so. He’ll play hookey this evening,and I’ll just be obleeged to make him work, tomorrow, to punish him. It’s mighty hard to make him work Saturdays, when all the boys is having holiday, but he hates work more than he hates anything else, and I’ve got to do some of my duty by him, or I’ll be the ruination of the child.”

His aunt Polly stood surprised a moment, and then broke into a gentle laugh. "Well, I never!" she exclaimed, shaking her head. "That boy is sharper than a tack. Just when I think I've got him cornered, he wriggles out like a greased pig!" She wiped her hands on her apron, still chuckling to herself.  

Tom had done it again—outsmarted her with his quick wit and charm. She had been certain he'd skipped his chores to go swimming, but there he stood, dry as a bone, spinning some wild tale about how he'd been studying his Bible verses all afternoon. And the worst part? She almost believed him.  

Polly sighed, half exasperated, half amused. She knew she ought to be stricter with the boy, but there was something about his mischievous grin that made it impossible to stay angry for long. "If I didn't love him so much," she muttered, "I'd tan his hide good and proper."  

Just then, she spotted the telltale white thread she'd sewn into Tom's shirt collar that morning—now loose and dangling. Her eyes narrowed. "So that's how he did it!" she realized. He *had* gone swimming, and he'd undone the stitches to trick her.  

Polly folded her arms, a slow smile creeping across her face. "Oh, Tom Sawyer," she murmured. "You may have won this round, but just you wait—I'll catch you yet."  

With that, she turned back to her kitchen, already plotting her next move. After all, outsmarting Tom was becoming her favorite game.

events.title: Tom's Return and Work Avoidance
detailed_summary: Tom follows through on his intention to play hooky and has an enjoyable time.
He returns home just in time to supposedly assist Jim, a young Black boy, with chopping wood for the next day and preparing kindling before supper.
However, Tom primarily narrates his adventures to Jim, while Jim ends up doing the vast majority (three-fourths) of the actual work.

In contrast, Tom's younger half-brother, Sid, is portrayed as a quiet and dutiful boy who has already finished his assigned chore of picking up wood chips, as he lacks Tom's adventurous and troublesome nature.

events.title: Aunt Polly's Interrogation and Sid's Betrayal
detailed_summary: During supper, while Tom discreetly steals sugar, Aunt Polly initiates a seemingly casual conversation designed to trap him into admitting he skipped school.
Aunt Polly fancies herself skilled in subtle diplomacy, though her tactics are rather obvious.
She inquires about the warmth at school, hoping to lead Tom towards a confession about swimming.
Tom becomes wary but responds noncommittally.
Aunt Polly then touches Tom's shirt, noting its dryness, and internally congratulates herself on this perceived clever discovery.
Tom, understanding her suspicion, quickly explains his damp hair by claiming some boys had pumped water on their heads.
Aunt Polly feels momentarily outwitted but then recalls that she had sewn Tom's shirt collar shut that morning.
She triumphantly asks Tom to unbutton his jacket, expecting to find the collar unsewn.
Tom confidently opens his jacket, revealing the collar is still securely sewn.
Aunt Polly, half-disappointed her deduction was wrong and half-glad Tom seemed obedient, tells him she forgives him this time.
Sid then points out a crucial detail: Aunt Polly had used white thread to sew the collar, but the thread currently on it is black.
Aunt Polly exclaims in realization, but Tom, knowing he's been caught, quickly makes his exit, muttering a threat to Sid for revealing the truth.

events.text_segment:
While Tom was eating his supper, and stealing sugar as opportunity offered, Aunt Polly asked him questions that were full of guile, and very deep—for she wanted to trap him into damaging revealments. Like many other simple-hearted souls, it was her pet vanity to believe she was endowed with a talent for dark and mysterious diplomacy, and she loved to contemplate her most transparent devices as marvels of low cunning. Said she:
“Tom, it was middling warm in school, warn’t it?”
“Yes’m.”
“Powerful warm, warn’t it?”
“Yes’m.”
“Didn’t you want to go in a-swimming, Tom?”
A bit of a scare shot through Tom—a touch of uncomfortable suspicion. He searched Aunt Polly’s face, but it told him nothing. So he said:
“No’m—well, not very much.”
The old lady reached out her hand and felt Tom’s shirt, and said:
“But you ain’t too warm now, though.” And it flattered her to reflect that she had discovered that the shirt was dry without anybody knowing that that was what she had in her mind. But in spite of her, Tom knew where the wind lay, now. So he forestalled what might be the next move:
“Some of us pumped on our heads—mine’s damp yet. See?”
Aunt Polly was vexed to think she had overlooked that bit of circumstantial evidence, and missed a trick. Then she had a new inspiration:
“Tom, you didn’t have to undo your shirt collar where I sewed it, to pump on your head, did you? Unbutton your jacket!”
The trouble vanished out of Tom’s face. He opened his jacket. His shirt collar was securely sewed.
“Bother! Well, go ’long with you. I’d made sure you’d played hookey and been a-swimming. But I forgive ye, Tom. I reckon you’re a kind of a singed cat, as the saying is—better’n you look. This time.”
She was half sorry her sagacity had miscarried, and half glad that Tom had stumbled into obedient conduct for once.
But Sidney said:
“Well, now, if I didn’t think you sewed his collar with white thread, but it’s black.”
“Why, I did sew it with white! Tom!”
But Tom did not wait for the rest. As he went out at the door he said:
“Siddy, I’ll lick you for that.”

While Tom was eating his supper, and stealing sugar as opportunity offered, Aunt Polly asked him questions that were full of guile, and very deep—for she wanted to trap him into damaging revealments. She fixed her spectacles firmly upon him, her sharp eyes boring into his very soul, as she inquired in a tone that was deceptively casual, "Tom, where were you this afternoon? I didn’t see you around the house after dinner."  

Tom, with a mouthful of bread and butter, hesitated just a fraction too long before answering. "Oh, I was just... out playin’ with the boys, Aunt Polly. Down by the creek."  

Aunt Polly’s lips tightened slightly. "Is that so? And what were you playin’ at, exactly?"  

Tom shifted in his seat, his fingers twitching toward the sugar bowl again. "Nothin’ much. Just skip-pin’ stones and such."  

She leaned forward, her voice dropping to a whisper. "Funny thing—I saw Sid comin’ back from the creek earlier, and he said he didn’t see hide nor hair of you there."  

Tom’s heart gave a guilty leap, but he forced a careless grin. "Well, Sid ain’t got the sharpest eyes, you know. Prob’ly just missed me."  

Aunt Polly’s gaze never wavered. "And another thing—your shirt’s got a tear in the sleeve. How’d that happen?"  

Tom glanced down at the offending rip, his mind racing. "Oh, that? Must’ve caught it on a fence or somethin’."  

"On a fence?" she echoed, skepticism dripping from every syllable. "Or maybe on a certain whitewashed fence while you were skulkin’ around instead of doin’ your chores?"  

Tom’s face flushed. He opened his mouth to protest, but Aunt Polly held up a hand. "Don’t bother lyin’, Tom Sawyer. I’ve already heard all about how you tricked those boys into whitewashin’ for you. Now, what do you have to say for yourself?"  

Trapped, Tom swallowed hard. There was no escaping Aunt Polly’s keen eye—or her justice.

events.title: Tom's Ingenuity, Resentment, and New Whistling Fascination
detailed_summary: Finding a private spot, Tom examines two needles concealed in his jacket lapels, one threaded with white and the other with black, confirming how he managed the collar deception.
He expresses frustration that Aunt Polly isn't consistent with her thread color choice, making his subterfuge more complicated.
He reaffirms his intention to punish Sid for exposing him.
The narrator comments that Tom is far from being the 'Model Boy' of the village, a type of boy Tom thoroughly detests.
Tom's anger and troubles quickly dissipate as a new, captivating interest takes hold of his mind.
This new preoccupation is a unique whistling technique, described as a bird-like warble, which he recently learned from a Black individual.
He is eager to practice this new skill without interruption.
Through focused effort, Tom masters the whistle and walks down the street feeling a profound sense of harmony and joy.
His pleasure in this new accomplishment is compared to that of an astronomer discovering a new planet, suggesting Tom's joy is even deeper and more pure.

In a safe place Tom examined two large needles which were thrust into the lapels of his jacket, and had thread bound about them—one needle carried white thread and the other black. He said:
“She’d never noticed if it hadn’t been for Sid. Confound it! sometimes she sews it with white, and sometimes she sews it with black. I wish to gee-miny she’d stick to one or t’other—I can’t keep the run of ’em. But I bet you I’ll lam Sid for that. I’ll learn him!”
He was not the Model Boy of the village. He knew the model boy very well though—and loathed him.
Within two minutes, or even less, he had forgotten all his troubles. Not because his troubles were one whit less heavy and bitter to him than a man’s are to a man, but because a new and powerful interest bore them down and drove them out of his mind for the time—just as men’s misfortunes are forgotten in the excitement of new enterprises. This new interest was a valued novelty in whistling, which he had just acquired from a negro, and he was suffering to practise it undisturbed. It consisted in a peculiar bird-like turn, a sort of liquid warble, produced by touching the tongue to the roof of the mouth at short intervals in the midst of the music—the reader probably remembers how to do it, if he has ever been a boy. Diligence and attention soon gave him the knack of it, and he strode down the street with his mouth full of harmony and his soul full of gratitude. He felt much as an astronomer feels who has discovered a new planet—no doubt, as far as strong, deep, unalloyed pleasure is concerned, the advantage was with the boy, not the astronomer.

Tom studied the needles with great curiosity, his mind racing with possibilities. The white thread and the black thread seemed to hold some hidden meaning—perhaps a secret code or a message from an unknown friend. He had found them mysteriously pinned to his jacket that morning, and now, hidden behind the old oak tree near the schoolhouse, he turned them over in his hands, frowning in thought.  

Could it be a signal from Huck Finn? Or maybe Becky Thatcher had left them as a secret token? Tom’s imagination ran wild. He recalled stories of pirates using coded messages, and his heart quickened at the idea of an adventure unfolding right before him.  

Carefully, he unwound the threads, examining them for any marks or knots that might reveal their purpose. The white thread was smooth and unbroken, while the black one had a tiny knot near the end. Tom’s eyes gleamed—this had to mean something!  

Just then, a rustling in the bushes startled him. He quickly tucked the needles back into his lapel and peered around the tree. Joe Harper’s freckled face appeared, grinning mischievously.  

“What’re you hidin’ for, Tom?” Joe asked.  

Tom hesitated, then decided to trust his friend. “Found these needles stuck in my coat,” he whispered. “Think it’s a sign?”  

Joe’s eyes widened. “Maybe it’s Injun Joe’s doin’! He’s been lurkin’ around town again.”  

A thrill shot through Tom. If the needles were a warning—or worse, a trap—then danger was near. Gripping the threads tightly, he made up his mind. “We gotta figure this out, Joe. And we gotta do it fast.”  

With that, the two boys set off, their hearts pounding with the promise of another mystery to solve.

events.title: Tom Encounters a Well-Dressed Newcomer
detailed_summary: The summer evening is long, and daylight still lingers.
Tom abruptly stops his whistling upon noticing a stranger before him – a boy slightly larger than himself.
The arrival of any newcomer, regardless of age or gender, is a significant event in the small, unassuming village of St. Petersburg.
This particular boy stands out because he is remarkably well-dressed for a weekday, sporting a fine cap, a new and stylish blue cloth suit, and pantaloons.
He is also wearing shoes, an uncommon sight on a Friday, and even has a necktie made of bright ribbon.

If one moved, the other moved—but only sidewise, in a circle; they kept face to face and eye to eye all the time. Finally Tom said:
“I can lick you!”
“I’d like to see you try it.”
“Well, I can do it.”
“No you can’t, either.”
“Yes I can.”
“No you can’t.”
“I can.”
“You can’t.”
“Can!”
“Can’t!”
An uncomfortable pause. Then Tom said:
“What’s your name?”
“’Tisn’t any of your business, maybe.”
“Well I ’low I’ll make it my business.”
“Well why don’t you?”
“If you say much, I will.”
“Much—much—much. There now.”
“Oh, you think you’re mighty smart, don’t you? I could lick you with one hand tied behind me, if I wanted to.”
“Well why don’t you do it? You say you can do it.”
“Well I will, if you fool with me.”
“Oh yes—I’ve seen whole families in the same fix.”
“Smarty! You think you’re some, now, don’t you? Oh, what a hat!”
“You can lump that hat if you don’t like it. I dare you to knock it off—and anybody that’ll take a dare will suck eggs.”
“You’re a liar!”
“You’re another.”
“You’re a fighting liar and dasn’t take it up.”
“Aw—take a walk!”
“Say—if you give me much more of your sass I’ll take and bounce a rock off’n your head.”
“Oh, of course you will.”
“Well I will.”
“Well why don’t you do it then? What do you keep saying you will for? Why don’t you do it? It’s because you’re afraid.”
“I ain’t afraid.”
“You are.”

events.text_segment:
Another pause, and more eying and sidling around each other. Presently they were shoulder to shoulder. Tom said:
“Get away from here!”
“Go away yourself!”
“I won’t.”
“I won’t either.”
So they stood, each with a foot placed at an angle as a brace, and both shoving with might and main, and glowering at each other with hate. But neither could get an advantage. After struggling till both were hot and flushed, each relaxed his strain with watchful caution, and Tom said:
“You’re a coward and a pup. I’ll tell my big brother on you, and he can thrash you with his little finger, and I’ll make him do it, too.”
“What do I care for your big brother? I’ve got a brother that’s bigger than he is—and what’s more, he can throw him over that fence, too.” [Both brothers were imaginary.]
“That’s a lie.”
“Your saying so don’t make it so.”
Tom drew a line in the dust with his big toe, and said:
“I dare you to step over that, and I’ll lick you till you can’t stand up. Anybody that’ll take a dare will steal sheep.”
The new boy stepped over promptly, and said:
“Now you said you’d do it, now let’s see you do it.”
“Don’t you crowd me now; you better look out.”
“Well, you said you’d do it—why don’t you do it?”
“By jingo! for two cents I will do it.”
The new boy took two broad coppers out of his pocket and held them out with derision. Tom struck them to the ground. In an instant both boys were rolling and tumbling in the dirt, gripped together like cats; and for the space of a minute they tugged and tore at each other’s hair and clothes, punched and scratched each other’s nose, and covered themselves with dust and glory. Presently the confusion took form, and through the fog of battle Tom appeared, seated astride the new boy, and pounding him with his fists. “Holler ’nuff!” said he.
The boy only struggled to free himself. He was crying—mainly from rage.
“Holler ’nuff!”—and the pounding went on.

events.text_segment:
Saturday morning was come, and all the summer world was bright and fresh, and brimming with life. There was a song in every heart; and if the heart was young the music issued at the lips. There was cheer in every face and a spring in every step. The locust-trees were in bloom and the fragrance of the blossoms filled the air. Cardiff Hill, beyond the village and above it, was green with vegetation and it lay just far enough away to seem a Delectable Land, dreamy, reposeful, and inviting.
Tom appeared on the sidewalk with a bucket of whitewash and a long-handled brush. He surveyed the fence, and all gladness left him and a deep melancholy settled down upon his spirit. Thirty yards of board fence nine feet high. Life to him seemed hollow, and existence but a burden. Sighing, he dipped his brush and passed it along the topmost plank; repeated the operation; did it again; compared the insignificant whitewashed streak with the far-reaching continent of unwhitewashed fence, and sat down on a tree-box discouraged. Jim came skipping out at the gate with a tin pail, and singing Buffalo Gals. Bringing water from the town pump had always been hateful work in Tom’s eyes, before, but now it did not strike him so. He remembered that there was company at the pump. White, mulatto, and negro boys and girls were always there waiting their turns, resting, trading playthings, quarrelling, fighting, skylarking. And he remembered that although the pump was only a hundred and fifty yards off, Jim never got back with a bucket of water under an hour—and even then somebody generally had to go after him. Tom said:
“Say, Jim, I’ll fetch the water if you’ll whitewash some.”
Jim shook his head and said:
“Can’t, Mars Tom. Ole missis, she tole me I got to go an’ git dis water an’ not stop foolin’ roun’ wid anybody. She say she spec’ Mars Tom gwine to ax me to whitewash, an’ so she tole me go ’long an’ ’tend to my own business—she ’lowed she’d ’tend to de whitewashin’.”
“Oh, never you mind what she said, Jim. That’s the way she always talks. Gimme the bucket—I won’t be gone only a a minute. She won’t ever know.”
“Oh, I dasn’t, Mars Tom. Ole missis she’d take an’ tar de head off’n me. ’Deed she would.”
“She! She never licks anybody—whacks ’em over the head with her thimble—and who cares for that, I’d like to know. She talks awful, but talk don’t hurt—anyways it don’t if she don’t cry. Jim, I’ll give you a marvel. I’ll give you a white alley!”
Jim began to waver.
“White alley, Jim! And it’s a bully taw.”
“My! Dat’s a mighty gay marvel, I tell you! But Mars Tom I’s powerful ’fraid ole missis—”
“And besides, if you will I’ll show you my sore toe.”
Jim was only human—this attraction was too much for him. He put down his pail, took the white alley, and bent over the toe with absorbing interest while the bandage was being unwound. In another moment he was flying down the street with his pail and a tingling rear, Tom was whitewashing with vigor, and Aunt Polly was retiring from the field with a slipper in her hand and triumph in her eye.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
Saturday morning was come, and all the summer world was bright and fresh, and brimming with life. The sun rose high over the sleepy town of St. Petersburg, casting golden rays upon the dew-kissed grass and the lazy Mississippi, which sparkled like a ribbon of silver. Birds chirped merrily in the trees, and the scent of blooming honeysuckle hung heavy in the warm air. It was the kind of morning that made a boy’s heart leap with the promise of adventure—and Tom Sawyer’s heart was no exception.  

Tom stood on the sidewalk with a bucket of whitewash and a long-handled brush, surveying the fence Aunt Polly had set him to whitewashing. Thirty yards of board fence, nine feet high—a task fit for a convict, not a free-spirited lad with mischief in his bones. His cheerful mood soured as he dipped the brush into the whitewash and made a feeble swipe at the wood. The job stretched before him like a prison sentence, and the more he thought about it, the more unbearable it became.  

Other boys would soon be passing by, free as the breeze, bound for swimming holes and secret hideouts. The thought gnawed at him. Jim, the slave boy, came sauntering down the street, whistling, a pail in hand.  

"Say, Jim," Tom called, "I’ll fetch the water for you if you’ll whitewash some."  

Jim shook his head. "Can’t, Marse Tom. Ole missis say I got to go to de pump an’ not stop foolin’ ’round wid anybody. She say she spec’ Marse Tom gwine to ax me to whitewash, an’ she say I better not."  

Tom’s shoulders slumped. Even Jim had orders to avoid his trap. He sighed and swiped another streak of whitewash onto the fence, his mind racing for an escape.  

Then, like a bolt of lightning, inspiration struck.  

Ben Rogers came skipping into view, munching on an apple and imitating the steady chug of a steamboat. Tom pretended not to see him, applying himself to his work with exaggerated care, as if it were the most fascinating task in the world.  

Ben stopped, his curiosity piqued. "Hello, old chap! Got to work, hey?"  

Tom turned, as if noticing him for the first time. "Why, it’s you, Ben! I warn’t noticing."  

"You ain’t going to work, are you?" Ben teased.  

Tom gave the fence another thoughtful stroke. "Well, maybe it is and maybe it ain’t. All I know is, it suits Tom Sawyer."  

Ben’s grin faltered. "Oh come now, you don’t mean to say you *like* it?"  

Tom stepped back, admiring his work. "Like it? Well, I don’t see why I oughtn’t to like it. Does a boy get a chance to whitewash a fence every day?"  

Ben’s apple hung forgotten in his hand. He watched as Tom dabbed the brush with artistic precision, adding a flourish here and there.  

"Say, Tom, let *me* whitewash a little."  

Tom pretended to consider. "No, no, Ben. Aunt Polly’s awful particular about this fence. It’s got to be done just so. I reckon there ain’t one boy in a thousand—maybe two thousand—that can do it the way it’s got to be done."  

Ben’s eyes widened. "Oh, please, Tom! Just let me try. I’ll give you the core of my apple!"  

Tom hesitated, then relented with a sigh. "Well, all right. But mind you do it careful."  

And so, with a sly grin hidden behind a mask of reluctance, Tom sat in the shade, munching Ben’s apple while Ben labored under the sun. By afternoon, a parade of boys had traded treasures—marbles, a kite string, a dead rat—for the privilege of whitewashing Aunt Polly’s fence.  

And Tom, the cunning general of childhood warfare, had discovered a great law of human action: that to make a boy covet a thing, it is only necessary to make the thing difficult to attain.

events.title: Despair and a Stroke of Genius
detailed_summary: Tom's newfound enthusiasm for whitewashing, prompted by Aunt Polly's intervention, quickly disappears.
He grows increasingly despondent as he reflects on the enjoyable activities he had planned for the day.

He takes out and examines his collection of personal belongings—various small toys, marbles, and other trinkets.
He concludes that his possessions might be sufficient to trade for a small amount of help, but are far from enough to secure even half an hour of genuine freedom.
Feeling disheartened, he puts his limited resources back into his pocket and dismisses the notion of trying to pay other boys to do his work.
At this moment of deep discouragement and hopelessness, a brilliant and magnificent idea strikes him.

He took up his brush and went tranquilly to work. Ben Rogers hove in sight presently—the very boy, of all boys, whose ridicule he had been dreading. Ben’s gait was the hop-skip-and-jump—proof enough that his heart was light and his anticipations high. He was eating an apple, and giving a long, melodious whoop, at intervals, followed by a deep-toned ding-dong-dong, ding-dong-dong, for he was personating a steamboat. As he drew near, he slackened speed, took the middle of the street, leaned far over to starboard and rounded to ponderously and with laborious pomp and circumstance—for he was personating the Big Missouri, and considered himself to be drawing nine feet of water. He was boat and captain and engine-bells combined, so he had to imagine himself standing on his own hurricane-deck giving the orders and executing them:
“Stop her, sir! Ting-a-ling-ling!” The headway ran almost out, and he drew up slowly toward the sidewalk.
“Ship up to back! Ting-a-ling-ling!” His arms straightened and stiffened down his sides.
“Set her back on the stabboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow! ch-chow-wow! Chow!” His right hand, mean-time, describing stately circles—for it was representing a forty-foot wheel.
“Let her go back on the labboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow-ch-chow-chow!” The left hand began to describe circles.
“Stop the stabboard! Ting-a-ling-ling! Stop the labboard! Come ahead on the stabboard! Stop her! Let your outside turn over slow! Ting-a-ling-ling! Chow-ow-ow! Get out that head-line! lively now! Come—out with your spring-line—what’re you about there! Take a turn round that stump with the bight of it! Stand by that stage, now—let her go! Done with the engines, sir! Ting-a-ling-ling! SH’T! S’H’T! SH’T!” (trying the gauge-cocks).
Tom went on whitewashing—paid no attention to the steamboat. Ben stared a moment and then said: “Hi-Yi! You’re up a stump, ain’t you!”
No answer. Tom surveyed his last touch with the eye of an artist, then he gave his brush another gentle sweep and surveyed the result, as before. Ben ranged up alongside of him. Tom’s mouth watered for the apple, but he stuck to his work. Ben said:
“Hello, old chap, you got to work, hey?”
Tom wheeled suddenly and said:
“Why, it’s you, Ben! I warn’t noticing.”
“Say—I’m going in a-swimming, I am. Don’t you wish you could? But of course you’d druther work—wouldn’t you? Course you would!”
Tom contemplated the boy a bit, and said:
“What do you call work?”
“Why, ain’t that work?”
Tom resumed his whitewashing, and answered carelessly:
“Well, maybe it is, and maybe it ain’t. All I know, is, it suits Tom Sawyer.”
“Oh come, now, you don’t mean to let on that you like it?”
The brush continued to move.
“Like it? Well, I don’t see why I oughtn’t to like it. Does a boy get a chance to whitewash a fence every day?”

He took up his brush and went tranquilly to work. The white fence stretched before him like a vast, unyielding enemy, but Tom was determined to conquer it. The sun beat down mercilessly, and the sweat trickled down his forehead, yet he refused to let his spirits sink. He dipped the brush into the bucket of whitewash and began the tedious task, each stroke a small victory against the endless wooden planks.  

For a while, he worked in silence, the only sound the rhythmic swish of the brush against the fence. But soon, his mind began to wander. He thought of the other boys, free to play and swim in the creek while he toiled under Aunt Polly’s orders. A deep sigh escaped him, and he paused, staring at the half-finished section. Then, a sly grin crept across his face.  

“Work?” he muttered to himself. “Why, this ain’t work. This here’s an art.”  

Just then, Ben Rogers came sauntering down the street, munching on an apple and looking as carefree as a bird in spring. Tom pretended not to notice him and redoubled his efforts, painting with exaggerated enthusiasm.  

“Hello, Tom!” Ben called. “Got to work, eh?”  

Tom turned, as if surprised, and gave Ben a knowing look. “Work? Oh, no, Ben. This ain’t work. This here’s a privilege. Aunt Polly wouldn’t trust just anybody with this fence. It’s got to be done just so.”  

Ben’s eyes widened with curiosity. He took another bite of his apple and stepped closer. “You mean you like doing it?”  

Tom shrugged, feigning indifference. “Well, I reckon there’s only one fence like this in town. And only one boy who can paint it proper.”  

Ben watched as Tom made another careful stroke, then another, his movements smooth and deliberate. The fence gleamed under the fresh coat of whitewash.  

“Say, Tom,” Ben said after a moment, “let me try a bit.”  

Tom shook his head. “Can’t do it, Ben. Aunt Polly’s mighty particular. She chose me special.”  

Ben’s face fell. “Aw, come on. Just a little bit?”  

Tom pretended to consider, then sighed. “Well… maybe just one stroke. But you got to be real careful.”  

Eagerly, Ben handed over his apple and took the brush. He dabbed at the fence, copying Tom’s motions. Before long, more boys wandered by, each one stopping to watch, then begging for a turn. By afternoon, the fence had three coats of whitewash, and Tom sat in the shade, his pockets jingling with treasures—marbles, a broken knife, a piece of blue bottle-glass—all traded for the privilege of painting.  

Aunt Polly came out later, astonished to find the job done. “Tom, how ever did you manage?”  

He grinned up at her, his eyes twinkling with mischief. “Some things just take the right touch, Aunt Polly.”  

And with that, he sauntered off, a boy who had turned labor into legend.

Tom said to himself that it was not such a hollow world, after all. He had discovered a great law of human action, without knowing it—namely, that in order to make a man or a boy covet a thing, it is only necessary to make the thing difficult to attain. If he had been a great and wise philosopher, like the writer of this book, he would now have comprehended that Work consists of whatever a body is obliged to do, and that Play consists of whatever a body is not obliged to do. And this would help him to understand why constructing artificial flowers or performing on a tread-mill is work, while rolling ten-pins or climbing Mont Blanc is only amusement. There are wealthy gentlemen in England who drive four-horse passenger-coaches twenty or thirty miles on a daily line, in the summer, because the privilege costs them considerable money; but if they were offered wages for the service, that would turn it into work and then they would resign.
The boy mused awhile over the substantial change which had taken place in his worldly circumstances, and then wended toward headquarters to report.

events.text_segment:
Tom presented himself before Aunt Polly, who was sitting by an open window in a pleasant rearward apartment, which was bedroom, breakfast-room, dining-room, and library, combined. The balmy summer air, the restful quiet, the odor of the flowers, and the drowsing murmur of the bees had had their effect, and she was nodding over her knitting—for she had no company but the cat, and it was asleep in her lap. Her spectacles were propped up on her gray head for safety. She had thought that of course Tom had deserted long ago, and she wondered at seeing him place himself in her power again in this intrepid way. He said: “Mayn’t I go and play now, aunt?”
“What, a’ready? How much have you done?”
“It’s all done, aunt.”
“Tom, don’t lie to me—I can’t bear it.”
“I ain’t, aunt; it is all done.”
Aunt Polly placed small trust in such evidence. She went out to see for herself; and she would have been content to find twenty per cent. of Tom’s statement true. When she found the entire fence white-washed, and not only whitewashed but elaborately coated and recoated, and even a streak added to the ground, her astonishment was almost unspeakable. She said:
“Well, I never! There’s no getting round it, you can work when you’re a mind to, Tom.” And then she diluted the compliment by adding, “But it’s powerful seldom you’re a mind to, I’m bound to say. Well, go ’long and play; but mind you get back some time in a week, or I’ll tan you.”
She was so overcome by the splendor of his achievement that she took him into the closet and selected a choice apple and delivered it to him, along with an improving lecture upon the added value and flavor a treat took to itself when it came without sin through virtuous effort. And while she closed with a happy Scriptural flourish, he “hooked” a doughnut.

Then he skipped out, and saw Sid just starting up the outside stairway that led to the back rooms on the second floor. Clods were handy and the air was full of them in a twinkling. They raged around Sid like a hail-storm; and before Aunt Polly could collect her surprised faculties and sally to the rescue, six or seven clods had taken personal effect, and Tom was over the fence and gone. There was a gate, but as a general thing he was too crowded for time to make use of it. His soul was at peace, now that he had settled with Sid for calling attention to his black thread and getting him into trouble.
Tom skirted the block, and came round into a muddy alley that led by the back of his aunt’s cow-stable. He presently got safely beyond the reach of capture and punishment, and hastened toward the public square of the village, where two “military” companies of boys had met for conflict, according to previous appointment. Tom was General of one of these armies, Joe Harper (a bosom friend) General of the other. These two great commanders did not condescend to fight in person—that being better suited to the still smaller fry—but sat together on an eminence and conducted the field operations by orders delivered through aides-de-camp. Tom’s army won a great victory, after a long and hard-fought battle. Then the dead were counted, prisoners exchanged, the terms of the next disagreement agreed upon, and the day for the necessary battle appointed; after which the armies fell into line and marched away, and Tom turned homeward alone.

events.title: Supper Antics, Scolding, and Sid's Sugar Bowl Mishap
detailed_summary: During supper, Tom's exuberant mood was so noticeable that Aunt Polly wondered about its cause.
He received a scolding for pelting Sid with clods earlier but seemed entirely unbothered by it.
He then attempted to sneak some sugar right under Aunt Polly's watch and received a rap on his knuckles for his audacity.
Tom pointed out that Sid was not punished for taking sugar.
Aunt Polly responded that Sid did not cause trouble the way Tom did and that Tom would constantly be into the sugar if not watched.
Shortly after, Aunt Polly went to the kitchen.
Sid, enjoying his perceived immunity and perhaps trying to gloat over Tom, reached for the sugar-bowl.
However, Sid's fingers slipped, and the sugar bowl fell and broke, much to Tom's delight as he foresaw Sid being blamed.

He said to himself, “Now it’s coming!” And the next instant he was sprawling on the floor! The potent palm was uplifted to strike again when Tom cried out:
“Hold on, now, what ’er you belting me for?—Sid broke it!”
Aunt Polly paused, perplexed, and Tom looked for healing pity. But when she got her tongue again, she only said:
“Umf! Well, you didn’t get a lick amiss, I reckon. You been into some other audacious mischief when I wasn’t around, like enough.”
Then her conscience reproached her, and she yearned to say something kind and loving; but she judged that this would be construed into a confession that she had been in the wrong, and discipline forbade that. So she kept silence, and went about her affairs with a troubled heart. Tom sulked in a corner and exalted his woes. He knew that in her heart his aunt was on her knees to him, and he was morosely gratified by the consciousness of it. He would hang out no signals, he would take notice of none. He knew that a yearning glance fell upon him, now and then, through a film of tears, but he refused recognition of it. He pictured himself lying sick unto death and his aunt bending over him beseeching one little forgiving word, but he would turn his face to the wall, and die with that word unsaid. Ah, how would she feel then? And he pictured himself brought home from the river, dead, with his curls all wet, and his sore heart at rest. How she would throw herself upon him, and how her tears would fall like rain, and her lips pray God to give her back her boy and she would never, never abuse him any more! But he would lie there cold and white and make no sign—a poor little sufferer, whose griefs were at an end. He so worked upon his feelings with the pathos of these dreams, that he had to keep swallowing, he was so like to choke; and his eyes swam in a blur of water, which overflowed when he winked, and ran down and trickled from the end of his nose. And such a luxury to him was this petting of his sorrows, that he could not bear to have any worldly cheeriness or any grating delight intrude upon it; it was too sacred for such contact; and so, presently, when his cousin Mary danced in, all alive with the joy of seeing home again after an age-long visit of one week to the country, he got up and moved in clouds and darkness out at one door as she brought song and sunshine in at the other.

A log raft in the river invited him, and he seated himself on its outer edge and contemplated the dreary vastness of the stream, wishing, the while, that he could only be drowned, all at once and unconsciously, without undergoing the uncomfortable routine devised by nature. At last he rose up sighing and departed in the darkness.

A log raft in the river invited him, and he seated himself on its outer edge and contemplated the dreary vastness of the stream, wishing, the while, that he could only be drowned, all at once and unconsciously, without undergoing the uncomfortable routine devised by nature. events.title: Nocturnal Vigil, Tragic Fantasies, and a Drenching Interruption
detailed_summary: Around nine-thirty or ten o'clock at night, Tom walked along the deserted street to the house where the girl he admired lived.
He paused, listening for any sound, and noticed a faint candlelight glowing through a curtain in a second-story window, wondering if she was inside.
He climbed the fence, moved stealthily through the plants, and positioned himself directly under the window.
He looked up at it for a long time with deep emotion.
Then, he lay down on his back on the ground beneath the window, hands clasped on his chest, holding the wilted pansy.
He imagined himself dying there in the cold, homeless and uncared for, with no one to comfort him in his final moments.
He envisioned the girl discovering his lifeless body in the morning and perhaps shedding a tear for his tragic, untimely demise.
Suddenly, the window above him opened, and a maid-servant's harsh voice shattered the quiet.
A large amount of water was thrown from the window, drenching Tom where he lay.

A small, indistinct figure was then seen quickly climbing over the fence and disappearing into the darkness.
Shortly thereafter, Tom was in his room, undressed for bed, examining his drenched clothes by candlelight when Sid awoke.
Sid, perhaps considering a sarcastic remark, observed the dangerous look in Tom's eyes and decided to remain silent.
Tom got into bed without saying his prayers, an omission that Sid duly noted.

events.title: Tom's Struggle with Bible Verses and a Prized Reward
detailed_summary: The day commenced with Aunt Polly conducting family worship, which involved a prayer constructed from Scriptural quotes and a reading from the Mosaic Law.
Tom then faced the task of memorizing his Bible verses, a chore Sid had accomplished days prior.
He chose five verses from the Sermon on the Mount for their brevity but struggled to focus, his mind drifting and his hands engaged in other activities.
Mary tried to assist him with his recitation, but Tom fumbled through the lines, needing constant prompting.
After expressing frustration and accusing Mary of being unkind, she gently encouraged him, offering a desirable reward for his success.
Spurred by curiosity and the promise of a prize, Tom applied himself earnestly and managed to learn the verses.
As a reward, Mary presented him with a new Barlow knife, valued at twelve and a half cents, which filled Tom with immense joy.
Despite the knife's poor cutting ability, Tom treasured it as a genuine Barlow, perceiving great value in it, and began to use it on furniture before being called to get ready for Sunday-school.

events.text_segment:
The sun rose upon a tranquil world, and beamed down upon the peaceful village like a benediction. Breakfast over, Aunt Polly had family worship: it began with a prayer built from the ground up of solid courses of Scriptural quotations, welded together with a thin mortar of originality; and from the summit of this she delivered a grim chapter of the Mosaic Law, as from Sinai.
Then Tom girded up his loins, so to speak, and went to work to “get his verses.” Sid had learned his lesson days before. Tom bent all his energies to the memorizing of five verses, and he chose part of the Sermon on the Mount, because he could find no verses that were shorter. At the end of half an hour Tom had a vague general idea of his lesson, but no more, for his mind was traversing the whole field of human thought, and his hands were busy with distracting recreations. Mary took his book to hear him recite, and he tried to find his way through the fog:
“Blessed are the—a—a—”
“Poor”—
“Yes—poor; blessed are the poor—a—a—”
“In spirit—”
“In spirit; blessed are the poor in spirit, for they—they—”
“Theirs—”
“For theirs. Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are they that mourn, for they—they—”
“Sh—”
“For they—a—”
“S, H, A—”
“For they S, H—Oh, I don’t know what it is!”
“Shall!”
“Oh, shall! for they shall—for they shall—a—a—shall mourn—a—a—blessed are they that shall—they that—a—they that shall mourn, for they shall—a—shall what? Why don’t you tell me, Mary?—what do you want to be so mean for?”
“Oh, Tom, you poor thick-headed thing, I’m not teasing you. I wouldn’t do that. You must go and learn it again. Don’t you be discouraged, Tom, you’ll manage it—and if you do, I’ll give you something ever so nice. There, now, that’s a good boy.”
“All right! What is it, Mary, tell me what it is.”
“Never you mind, Tom. You know if I say it’s nice, it is nice.”
“You bet you that’s so, Mary. All right, I’ll tackle it again.”
And he did “tackle it again”—and under the double pressure of curiosity and prospective gain he did it with such spirit that he accomplished a shining success. Mary gave him a brand-new “Barlow” knife worth twelve and a half cents; and the convulsion of delight that swept his system shook him to his foundations. True, the knife would not cut anything, but it was a “sure-enough” Barlow, and there was inconceivable grandeur in that—though where the Western boys ever got the idea that such a weapon could possibly be counterfeited to its injury is an imposing mystery and will always remain so, perhaps. Tom contrived to scarify the cupboard with it, and was arranging to begin on the bureau, when he was called off to dress for Sunday-school.

The sun rose upon a tranquil world, and beamed down upon the peaceful village like a benediction. The Mississippi River glistened under its golden touch, and the sleepy town of St. Petersburg stirred to life. Birds chirped in the trees, and the scent of fresh-baked bread drifted from Aunt Polly’s kitchen. It was a morning that promised adventure, and Tom Sawyer was determined to seize it.  

Tom lay sprawled on his back in the tall grass behind the Widow Douglas’s house, chewing lazily on a blade of grass. His bare feet were dirty, his straw hat tilted over his eyes, and his mind was busy plotting the day’s mischief. He had already skipped Sunday school—again—and now he was considering whether to go fishing or to hunt for buried treasure. Treasure, he decided, was far more exciting.  

Just then, he heard the familiar whistle of his best friend, Huckleberry Finn. Tom sat up, grinning as Huck sauntered over, his ragged clothes and bare feet a testament to his carefree existence.  

“What’s the plan, Tom?” Huck asked, flopping down beside him.  

Tom’s eyes gleamed. “I reckon we oughta dig for pirate gold today. There’s bound to be some buried near the old haunted house up on Cardiff Hill.”  

Huck scratched his head. “Ain’t that place cursed?”  

“All the better!” Tom declared. “Nobody’ll dare look there, so the treasure’s sure to be left for us.”  

With that, the two boys set off, their pockets stuffed with a few rusty nails (which Tom insisted could be used as magical charms) and a piece of chalk to mark their trail. The path to Cardiff Hill wound through dense woods, where sunlight filtered through the leaves in dappled patterns. Tom led the way, his imagination already painting pictures of chests overflowing with gold doubloons and jeweled daggers.  

When they reached the creaky old house, its broken windows and sagging porch sent a shiver down Huck’s spine. “You go first,” he muttered.  

Tom, though secretly nervous, puffed out his chest. “Ain’t nothin’ to be scared of,” he said, pushing open the door with a dramatic flourish.  

Inside, dust motes danced in the sunlight, and the floorboards groaned under their weight. Tom’s heart pounded, but he refused to show fear. They tiptoed through the empty rooms, tapping the walls for hollow spots. Just as they were about to give up, Tom’s foot struck a loose floorboard. With a whoop, he pried it up—and there, nestled in the darkness, was a small, rusted tin box.  

Huck’s eyes widened. “You don’t think—”  

Tom lifted the lid with trembling hands. Inside lay a handful of tarnished coins, a faded map, and a single gold ring. It wasn’t a king’s ransom, but to them, it was a fortune.  

“We’re rich!” Tom crowed, dancing a jig.  

Huck grinned. “Reckon we oughta celebrate with some licorice and a swim?”  

Tom clapped him on the back. “Best idea you ever had, Huck Finn!”  

And with that, the two boys raced back toward town, their pockets jingling with treasure, their hearts full of dreams, and the sun shining down on them like it was the start of another grand adventure.

events.title: Tom's Reluctant Sunday School Preparations
detailed_summary: Mary provided Tom with a basin of water and soap for washing.
Tom attempted to evade a thorough washing by merely going through the motions and then drying his face in the kitchen.
Mary caught his deception, refilled the basin, and insisted he wash properly, reminding him that water is not harmful.
After some hesitation, Tom washed his face, emerging with soap and water as evidence but with a clear demarcation line at his chin and neck, leaving the lower areas unwashed.
Mary intervened and completed his grooming, ensuring he was clean all over, and his wet hair was neatly brushed into curls.
Tom, disliking curls which he considered effeminate, secretly tried to flatten his hair.
Mary then laid out his Sunday suit, referred to as his "other clothes," indicating his limited wardrobe.

After Tom dressed, Mary made final adjustments, buttoning his roundabout, arranging his collar, brushing him, and placing his hat on his head, resulting in an improved but uncomfortable appearance for Tom.
Tom felt constrained by the cleanliness and formal attire and hoped Mary would forget his shoes, but she polished them with tallow and presented them.
He expressed his irritation at being forced to do things he disliked, but Mary's persuasive appeal led him to put on the shoes grudgingly.
Soon after, Mary, Tom, and Sid departed for Sunday-school, an institution Tom deeply disliked, unlike his siblings.

Mary gave him a tin basin of water and a piece of soap, and he went outside the door and set the basin on a little bench there; then he dipped the soap in the water and laid it down; turned up his sleeves; poured out the water on the ground, gently, and then entered the kitchen and began to wipe his face diligently on the towel behind the door. But Mary removed the towel and said:
“Now ain’t you ashamed, Tom. You mustn’t be so bad. Water won’t hurt you.”
Tom was a trifle disconcerted. The basin was refilled, and this time he stood over it a little while, gathering resolution; took in a big breath and began. When he entered the kitchen presently, with both eyes shut and groping for the towel with his hands, an honorable testimony of suds and water was dripping from his face. But when he emerged from the towel, he was not yet satisfactory, for the clean territory stopped short at his chin and his jaws, like a mask; below and beyond this line there was a dark expanse of unirrigated soil that spread downward in front and backward around his neck. Mary took him in hand, and when she was done with him he was a man and a brother, without distinction of color, and his saturated hair was neatly brushed, and its short curls wrought into a dainty and symmetrical general effect. [He privately smoothed out the curls, with labor and difficulty, and plastered his hair close down to his head; for he held curls to be effeminate, and his own filled his life with bitterness.] Then Mary got out a suit of his clothing that had been used only on Sundays during two years—they were simply called his “other clothes”—and so by that we know the size of his wardrobe. The girl “put him to rights” after he had dressed himself; she buttoned his neat roundabout up to his chin, turned his vast shirt collar down over his shoulders, brushed him off and crowned him with his speckled straw hat. He now looked exceedingly improved and uncomfortable. He was fully as uncomfortable as he looked; for there was a restraint about whole clothes and cleanliness that galled him. He hoped that Mary would forget his shoes, but the hope was blighted; she coated them thoroughly with tallow, as was the custom, and brought them out. He lost his temper and said he was always being made to do everything he didn’t want to do. But Mary said, persuasively:
“Please, Tom—that’s a good boy.”
So he got into the shoes snarling. Mary was soon ready, and the three children set out for Sunday-school—a place that Tom hated with his whole heart; but Sid and Mary were fond of it.

But Mary, sharp-eyed as ever, caught him in the act.  

“Tom Sawyer!” she exclaimed, hands on her hips. “You think I don’t know what you’re up to? That towel’s clean, and now you’ve gone and smeared dirt all over it!”  

Tom dropped the towel with a guilty start. “I *was* washin’,” he protested, though his face bore no trace of soap or water. “Just forgot the soap part, is all.”  

Mary marched him back outside, pointing at the untouched basin. “You’ll do it proper this time, or no breakfast for you.”  

Grumbling, Tom picked up the soap and made a show of scrubbing his face, though most of the water ended up on his shirtfront. He splashed noisily, sending droplets flying, then shook his head like a wet dog, spraying the porch.  

“There!” he announced, holding out his arms. “Clean as a preacher on Sunday.”  

Mary sighed. “Your ears, Tom.”  

“What about ’em?”  

“They’re still black as soot.”  

Tom groaned but dragged the soap over one ear halfheartedly. “Ain’t nobody studyin’ my ears.”  

“*I* am,” Mary said firmly. “And Aunt Polly will too. Now hurry up—Sid’s already at the table.”  

At the mention of Sid, Tom’s face darkened. That goody-goody cousin of his never missed a chance to tattle. With a sudden burst of energy, Tom scrubbed his ears raw, splashed water everywhere, and even—for a fleeting second—considered washing behind his neck. But the thought of Sid enjoying his ham and eggs unchallenged was too much to bear.  

Dripping and triumphant, he thrust the basin at Mary. “Satisfied?”  

She inspected him critically. “Well, you’re *wetter*,” she admitted. “Go on, then. But if Aunt Polly finds dirt—”  

Tom didn’t wait for the rest. He bolted inside, the screen door slamming behind him, his so-called cleanliness already forgotten in the race to claim the biggest piece of bacon before Sid could steal it.  

Mary shook her head, picking up the abandoned soap. Some battles, she supposed, were never truly won.

He continued to acquire more tickets of various colors—red and blue—by bartering with other boys for about ten to fifteen minutes.
Tom then joined a crowd of children entering the church, found his seat, and promptly started a dispute with a nearby boy.

Ten yellow tickets could be redeemed for a plainly bound Bible, a feat rarely achieved due to the immense effort of memorizing two thousand verses.
The narrative mentions Mary's diligence in earning two Bibles and a German boy who won several, though the latter suffered mentally from the strain.
Winning a Bible was a significant event, bringing temporary fame and inspiring ambition in other students, and Tom, while not necessarily wanting the Bible itself, craved the associated glory.

events.text_segment:
Sabbath-school hours were from nine to half-past ten; and then church service. Two of the children always remained for the sermon voluntarily, and the other always remained too—for stronger reasons. The church’s high-backed, uncushioned pews would seat about three hundred persons; the edifice was but a small, plain affair, with a sort of pine board tree-box on top of it for a steeple. At the door Tom dropped back a step and accosted a Sunday-dressed comrade:
“Say, Billy, got a yaller ticket?”
“Yes.”
“What’ll you take for her?”
“What’ll you give?”
“Piece of lickrish and a fish-hook.”
“Less see ’em.”
Tom exhibited. They were satisfactory, and the property changed hands. Then Tom traded a couple of white alleys for three red tickets, and some small trifle or other for a couple of blue ones. He waylaid other boys as they came, and went on buying tickets of various colors ten or fifteen minutes longer. He entered the church, now, with a swarm of clean and noisy boys and girls, proceeded to his seat and started a quarrel with the first boy that came handy. The teacher, a grave, elderly man, interfered; then turned his back a moment and Tom pulled a boy’s hair in the next bench, and was absorbed in his book when the boy turned around; stuck a pin in another boy, presently, in order to hear him say “Ouch!” and got a new reprimand from his teacher. Tom’s whole class were of a pattern—restless, noisy, and troublesome. When they came to recite their lessons, not one of them knew his verses perfectly, but had to be prompted all along. However, they worried through, and each got his reward—in small blue tickets, each with a passage of Scripture on it; each blue ticket was pay for two verses of the recitation. Ten blue tickets equalled a red one, and could be exchanged for it; ten red tickets equalled a yellow one; for ten yellow tickets the superintendent gave a very plainly bound Bible (worth forty cents in those easy times) to the pupil. How many of my readers would have the industry and application to memorize two thousand verses, even for a Doré Bible? And yet Mary had acquired two Bibles in this way—it was the patient work of two years—and a boy of German parentage had won four or five. He once recited three thousand verses without stopping; but the strain upon his mental faculties was too great, and he was little better than an idiot from that day forth—a grievous misfortune for the school, for on great occasions, before company, the superintendent (as Tom expressed it) had always made this boy come out and “spread himself.” Only the older pupils managed to keep their tickets and stick to their tedious work long enough to get a Bible, and so the delivery of one of these prizes was a rare and noteworthy circumstance; the successful pupil was so great and conspicuous for that day that on the spot every scholar’s heart was fired with a fresh ambition that often lasted a couple of weeks. It is possible that Tom’s mental stomach had never really hungered for one of those prizes, but unquestionably his entire being had for many a day longed for the glory and the eclat that came with it.

Sabbath-school hours were from nine to half-past ten; and then church service. Tom Sawyer, with his usual reluctance toward anything resembling discipline, dragged himself to Sunday school that morning, his pockets stuffed with treasures—tickets earned for memorizing Bible verses, a dead rat on a string, and a handful of marbles. He had no real interest in the lessons, but he did have an interest in the rewards: a blue ticket for two verses, a red for ten, and the coveted prize Bible for a thousand.  

The school was held in the same building as the church, a plain, whitewashed structure that seemed to sigh under the weight of its own solemnity. Benches were lined up in neat rows, and the superintendent, a thin, severe man with spectacles perched on his nose, stood at the front, surveying the children with an air of weary authority.  

Tom had no intention of reciting any verses that day. Instead, he busied himself with trading his tickets for trivial treasures—a piece of chalk here, a fishhook there—until he found himself in possession of just enough to barter for a yellow ticket, which was of no real value except to inflate his own sense of accomplishment.  

The highlight of the morning came when Judge Thatcher, a man of great importance in the village, entered with his family. Tom’s eyes immediately fixed on the judge’s daughter, Becky Thatcher, a pretty little girl with golden curls and a dress as white as Sunday itself. Suddenly, the idea of earning that prize Bible didn’t seem so foolish. If he could impress Becky, perhaps she would look at him the way the other girls did when the minister’s son recited his verses with practiced solemnity.  

With sudden determination, Tom marched up to the superintendent and presented his collection of tickets—enough, by some miracle of last-minute trading, to claim the prize. The room buzzed with surprise. Tom Sawyer, of all people, had won the Bible! The superintendent, though skeptical, had no choice but to acknowledge the feat.  

Then came the test.  

“Now, Thomas,” the superintendent said, adjusting his spectacles, “since you have earned this honor, perhaps you would favor us by reciting some of the verses you have learned.”  

A hush fell over the room. Tom’s mind went blank. He had memorized nothing. Sweat prickled at his temples as he fumbled for an answer. The silence stretched, unbearable, until at last, the superintendent sighed and handed him the Bible with a look of resigned disappointment.  

Tom took his seat, the weight of the book heavy in his hands, his triumph hollow. Becky’s eyes, wide with admiration only moments before, now held a flicker of doubt.  

Church service followed, and though the minister’s sermon thundered with warnings of sin and redemption, Tom’s thoughts were elsewhere—on pirate treasure, on whitewashing fences, on anything but the droning voice filling the stifling air.  

By the time the final hymn was sung, Tom had already plotted his escape—not just from the church, but from the entire oppressive weight of Sunday respectability. There were frogs to catch, adventures to be had, and a certain Becky Thatcher to impress in ways that didn’t involve Bible verses.

events.text_segment:
In due course the superintendent stood up in front of the pulpit, with a closed hymn-book in his hand and his forefinger inserted between its leaves, and commanded attention. When a Sunday-school superintendent makes his customary little speech, a hymn-book in the hand is as necessary as is the inevitable sheet of music in the hand of a singer who stands forward on the platform and sings a solo at a concert—though why, is a mystery: for neither the hymn-book nor the sheet of music is ever referred to by the sufferer. This superintendent was a slim creature of thirty-five, with a sandy goatee and short sandy hair; he wore a stiff standing-collar whose upper edge almost reached his ears and whose sharp points curved forward abreast the corners of his mouth—a fence that compelled a straight lookout ahead, and a turning of the whole body when a side view was required; his chin was propped on a spreading cravat which was as broad and as long as a bank-note, and had fringed ends; his boot toes were turned sharply up, in the fashion of the day, like sleigh-runners—an effect patiently and laboriously produced by the young men by sitting with their toes pressed against a wall for hours together. Mr. Walters was very earnest of mien, and very sincere and honest at heart; and he held sacred things and places in such reverence, and so separated them from worldly matters, that unconsciously to himself his Sunday-school voice had acquired a peculiar intonation which was wholly absent on week-days. He began after this fashion:
“Now, children, I want you all to sit up just as straight and pretty as you can and give me all your attention for a minute or two. There—that is it. That is the way good little boys and girls should do. I see one little girl who is looking out of the window—I am afraid she thinks I am out there somewhere—perhaps up in one of the trees making a speech to the little birds. [Applausive titter.] I want to tell you how good it makes me feel to see so many bright, clean little faces assembled in a place like this, learning to do right and be good.” And so forth and so on. It is not necessary to set down the rest of the oration. It was of a pattern which does not vary, and so it is familiar to us all.
The latter third of the speech was marred by the resumption of fights and other recreations among certain of the bad boys, and by fidgetings and whisperings that extended far and wide, washing even to the bases of isolated and incorruptible rocks like Sid and Mary. But now every sound ceased suddenly, with the subsidence of Mr. Walters’ voice, and the conclusion of the speech was received with a burst of silent gratitude.
A good part of the whispering had been occasioned by an event which was more or less rare—the entrance of visitors: lawyer Thatcher, accompanied by a very feeble and aged man; a fine, portly, middle-aged gentleman with iron-gray hair; and a dignified lady who was doubtless the latter’s wife. The lady was leading a child. Tom had been restless and full of chafings and repinings; conscience-smitten, too—he could not meet Amy Lawrence’s eye, he could not brook her loving gaze. But when he saw this small newcomer his soul was all ablaze with bliss in a moment. The next moment he was “showing off” with all his might—cuffing boys, pulling hair, making faces—in a word, using every art that seemed likely to fascinate a girl and win her applause. His exaltation had but one alloy—the memory of his humiliation in this angel’s garden—and that record in sand was fast washing out, under the waves of happiness that were sweeping over it now.

In due course the superintendent stood up in front of the pulpit, with a closed hymn-book in his hand and his forefinger inserted between its leaves, and commanded attention. A hush fell over the congregation as all eyes turned toward him. Even the restless children, who had been fidgeting in their seats, grew still under his stern gaze.  

The superintendent cleared his throat and began in a solemn tone, "We shall now proceed with the recitation of the Sunday school verses. Those who have committed their verses to memory will please step forward."  

A murmur of anticipation rippled through the room. Tom Sawyer, who had spent the better part of the previous evening attempting—and failing—to memorize his assigned scripture, shifted uncomfortably in his seat. He glanced around, noting with dismay the confident expressions of the other boys and girls who had clearly prepared.  

One by one, the children rose and made their way to the front, reciting their verses with varying degrees of success. Some spoke clearly and without hesitation, earning nods of approval from the superintendent. Others stumbled over their words, their faces flushing with embarrassment as they struggled to remember.  

Tom watched with growing dread. He had hoped to rely on his usual charm to avoid the ordeal, but the superintendent’s sharp eyes missed nothing. When his turn came, Tom stood reluctantly, his mind racing for an escape. Then, an idea struck him—a desperate one, but better than admitting defeat.  

With a deep breath, he marched forward, his face the picture of solemn piety. The superintendent regarded him expectantly. Tom hesitated dramatically, then began in a slow, reverent voice, "Blessed are the—the..." He paused, as if overcome with emotion.  

The superintendent frowned. "Go on, Thomas."  

Tom sighed heavily. "I’m afraid I can’t continue, sir. The words are too sacred. I—I feel unworthy to speak them."  

A ripple of surprise passed through the room. The superintendent’s stern expression softened slightly. "That is a commendable sentiment, my boy, but the Lord wishes us to share His word with humility, not fear."  

Tom bowed his head. "Yes, sir. It’s just... I’ve been thinking so much about the meaning of the verses that I—I forgot the exact words."  

The superintendent studied him for a long moment, then nodded. "Very well. You may return to your seat. But I trust you will reflect on this and be better prepared next Sunday."  

Tom retreated, suppressing a grin. He had escaped again—not through diligence, but through cleverness. As he slid back into his seat, he caught the admiring glances of his peers. Even Becky Thatcher, the prettiest girl in school, seemed impressed by his performance.  

The superintendent, unaware of Tom’s deception, turned back to the congregation. "Let this be a lesson to all," he intoned. "The word of God is not to be taken lightly. Those who neglect their spiritual duties do so at their own peril."  

Tom barely listened. His mind was already racing ahead to the afternoon’s adventures—fishing, swimming, or perhaps playing pirates with Huck Finn. Sunday school was over, and freedom awaited.  

As the final hymn was sung and the congregation dispersed, Tom slipped out the door, his heart light. Another week of mischief and excitement lay before him, and he intended to make the most of it. After all, in the world of Tom Sawyer, every day was an adventure waiting to happen.

events.title: The Impact of Judge Thatcher's Presence and Widespread 'Showing Off'
detailed_summary: The newly arrived visitors were given the most prominent seats.
After his speech, Mr. Walters introduced them, revealing the portly gentleman to be the esteemed county judge, Judge Thatcher, which awed the children.
The children were impressed that the Judge was from Constantinople, a town twelve miles away, and had seen the county court-house.
Jeff Thatcher, a local boy, eagerly went forward to interact with the Judge, hoping to be envied by his peers.
This prompted a wave of ostentatious behavior, or "showing off," throughout the Sunday-school.
Mr. Walters bustled about with official activities, the librarian scurried with books, and the young lady teachers adopted sweet demeanors towards their pupils.
Young gentlemen teachers also engaged in minor displays of authority.
Many teachers found reasons to be near the pulpit and library, often repeating tasks unnecessarily.
The little girls and boys also participated in this display, with the boys creating a commotion with paper wads and scuffling.
Presiding over this scene, Judge Thatcher himself appeared to enjoy the attention, beaming majestically.

events.text_segment:
The visitors were given the highest seat of honor, and as soon as Mr. Walters’ speech was finished, he introduced them to the school. The middle-aged man turned out to be a prodigious personage—no less a one than the county judge—altogether the most august creation these children had ever looked upon—and they wondered what kind of material he was made of—and they half wanted to hear him roar, and were half afraid he might, too. He was from Constantinople, twelve miles away—so he had travelled, and seen the world—these very eyes had looked upon the county court-house—which was said to have a tin roof. The awe which these reflections inspired was attested by the impressive silence and the ranks of staring eyes. This was the great Judge Thatcher, brother of their own lawyer. Jeff Thatcher immediately went forward, to be familiar with the great man and be envied by the school. It would have been music to his soul to hear the whisperings:
“Look at him, Jim! He’s a going up there. Say—look! he’s a going to shake hands with him—he is shaking hands with him! By jings, don’t you wish you was Jeff?”
Mr. Walters fell to “showing off,” with all sorts of official bustlings and activities, giving orders, delivering judgments, discharging directions here, there, everywhere that he could find a target. The librarian “showed off”—running hither and thither with his arms full of books and making a deal of the splutter and fuss that insect authority delights in. The young lady teachers “showed off”—bending sweetly over pupils that were lately being boxed, lifting pretty warning fingers at bad little boys and patting good ones lovingly. The young gentlemen teachers “showed off” with small scoldings and other little displays of authority and fine attention to discipline—and most of the teachers, of both sexes, found business up at the library, by the pulpit; and it was business that frequently had to be done over again two or three times (with much seeming vexation). The little girls “showed off” in various ways, and the little boys “showed off” with such diligence that the air was thick with paper wads and the murmur of scufflings. And above it all the great man sat and beamed a majestic judicial smile upon all the house, and warmed himself in the sun of his own grandeur—for he was “showing off,” too.

There was only one thing wanting to make Mr. Walters’ ecstasy complete, and that was a chance to deliver a Bible-prize and exhibit a prodigy. The Sunday-school superintendent had long dreamed of the moment when he could present a gleaming new Bible to some exceptionally bright and pious scholar, thereby setting an example for all the other children to follow. He imagined the scene vividly—the hushed reverence of the room, the envious whispers of the pupils, and the proud glow on the face of the chosen one.  

But alas, such a moment had never come. The boys of St. Petersburg were not known for their diligent memorization of Scripture, and the few who did manage to recite enough verses to earn the prize were usually so dull and unremarkable that their triumph inspired little admiration. Mr. Walters had nearly given up hope when, one fateful Sunday, Tom Sawyer sauntered into the classroom with an air of quiet confidence.  

Tom, of course, had no real intention of earning a Bible through honest study. Instead, he had struck a clever bargain, trading an assortment of trinkets—a piece of blue bottle-glass, a broken knife, a spool—for the tickets that marked recitations. It was a scheme only Tom could devise, and by the time Mr. Walters called for the prize to be awarded, he had amassed enough to claim the coveted reward.  

The superintendent’s heart swelled with joy as he beheld Tom standing before him, the very picture of a model scholar. Here, at last, was the prodigy he had longed for! With great ceremony, Mr. Walters presented the Bible, praising Tom’s supposed devotion to Scripture and urging the other children to follow his example. The room buzzed with astonishment—no one could believe that Tom Sawyer, of all people, had won the prize.  

But the true climax came when Judge Thatcher, a distinguished visitor that day, requested the honor of shaking the young scholar’s hand. Tom, basking in his undeserved glory, nearly fainted from the sheer audacity of his success. Mr. Walters, meanwhile, reveled in his moment of triumph, blissfully unaware that his shining example of virtue was, in fact, the craftiest little fraud in St. Petersburg.  

And so, for one glorious Sunday, the superintendent’s dream was fulfilled—even if it was built upon the most delightful deception.

events.text_segment:
Tom was introduced to the Judge; but his tongue was tied, his breath would hardly come, his heart quaked—partly because of the awful greatness of the man, but mainly because he was her parent. He would have liked to fall down and worship him, if it were in the dark. The Judge put his hand on Tom’s head and called him a fine little man, and asked him what his name was. The boy stammered, gasped, and got it out:
“Tom.”
“Oh, no, not Tom—it is—”
“Thomas.”
“Ah, that’s it. I thought there was more to it, maybe. That’s very well. But you’ve another one I daresay, and you’ll tell it to me, won’t you?”
“Tell the gentleman your other name, Thomas,” said Walters, “and say sir. You mustn’t forget your manners.”
“Thomas Sawyer—sir.”
“That’s it! That’s a good boy. Fine boy. Fine, manly little fellow. Two thousand verses is a great many—very, very great many. And you never can be sorry for the trouble you took to learn them; for knowledge is worth more than anything there is in the world; it’s what makes great men and good men; you’ll be a great man and a good man yourself, some day, Thomas, and then you’ll look back and say, It’s all owing to the precious Sunday-school privileges of my boyhood—it’s all owing to my dear teachers that taught me to learn—it’s all owing to the good superintendent, who encouraged me, and watched over me, and gave me a beautiful Bible—a splendid elegant Bible—to keep and have it all for my own, always—it’s all owing to right bringing up! That is what you will say, Thomas—and you wouldn’t take any money for those two thousand verses—no indeed you wouldn’t. And now you wouldn’t mind telling me and this lady some of the things you’ve learned—no, I know you wouldn’t—for we are proud of little boys that learn. Now, no doubt you know the names of all the twelve disciples. Won’t you tell us the names of the first two that were appointed?”
Tom was tugging at a button-hole and looking sheepish. He blushed, now, and his eyes fell. Mr. Walters’ heart sank within him. He said to himself, it is not possible that the boy can answer the simplest question—why did the Judge ask him? Yet he felt obliged to speak up and say:
“Answer the gentleman, Thomas—don’t be afraid.”
Tom still hung fire.
“Now I know you’ll tell me,” said the lady. “The names of the first two disciples were—”
“David and Goliah!”
Let us draw the curtain of charity over the rest of the scene.

Tom grinned, his usual confidence creeping back. Maybe, just maybe, he had won more than just Becky’s admiration that day.  

And as he stood there, surrounded by the townspeople’s praise, Tom realized something—sometimes, the scariest moments led to the greatest rewards.

The Sunday-school children distributed themselves about the house and occupied pews with their parents, so as to be under supervision.
