He always brought his mother to church, and was the pride of all the matrons. The boys all hated him, he was so good. And besides, he had been “thrown up to them” so much. His white handkerchief was hanging out of his pocket behind, as usual on Sundays—accidentally. Tom had no handkerchief, and he looked upon boys who had as snobs.

events.title: The Minister's Expansive Prayer and Tom's Fly Distraction
detailed_summary: The minister commenced a comprehensive and far-reaching prayer.

The prayer addressed the local church, its children, other village churches, the village, county, state, national government officials, sailors, oppressed populations under foreign rule, those spiritually blind, and heathens in distant lands.
It concluded with a plea for his upcoming sermon to be received favorably and yield positive results.
After the prayer, the standing congregation sat down.
Tom Sawyer found the prayer tedious, merely tolerating it without genuine attention.
He mentally noted the prayer's familiar structure, resenting any deviations or additions as unfair.
During the prayer, a fly landed on the pew ahead of Tom, capturing his attention with its meticulous grooming.
Tom was deeply tempted to catch the fly but refrained, believing it would endanger his soul to do so during prayer.
The moment the prayer concluded with "Amen," Tom swiftly captured the fly.
His aunt observed his action and compelled him to release the insect.

events.text_segment:
And now the minister prayed. A good, generous prayer it was, and went into details: it pleaded for the church, and the little children of the church; for the other churches of the village; for the village itself; for the county; for the State; for the State officers; for the United States; for the churches of the United States; for Congress; for the President; for the officers of the Government; for poor sailors, tossed by stormy seas; for the oppressed millions groaning under the heel of European monarchies and Oriental despotisms; for such as have the light and the good tidings, and yet have not eyes to see nor ears to hear withal; for the heathen in the far islands of the sea; and closed with a supplication that the words he was about to speak might find grace and favor, and be as seed sown in fertile ground, yielding in time a grateful harvest of good. Amen.
There was a rustling of dresses, and the standing congregation sat down. The boy whose history this book relates did not enjoy the prayer, he only endured it—if he even did that much. He was restive all through it; he kept tally of the details of the prayer, unconsciously—for he was not listening, but he knew the ground of old, and the clergyman’s regular route over it—and when a little trifle of new matter was interlarded, his ear detected it and his whole nature resented it; he considered additions unfair, and scoundrelly. In the midst of the prayer a fly had lit on the back of the pew in front of him and tortured his spirit by calmly rubbing its hands together, embracing its head with its arms, and polishing it so vigorously that it seemed to almost part company with the body, and the slender thread of a neck was exposed to view; scraping its wings with its hind legs and smoothing them to its body as if they had been coat-tails; going through its whole toilet as tranquilly as if it knew it was perfectly safe. As indeed it was; for as sorely as Tom’s hands itched to grab for it they did not dare—he believed his soul would be instantly destroyed if he did such a thing while the prayer was going on. But with the closing sentence his hand began to curve and steal forward; and the instant the “Amen” was out the fly was a prisoner of war. His aunt detected the act and made him let it go.

Tom fidgeted in his seat, his mind wandering far from the solemn words. He stole glances at the ceiling, counting the cracks in the plaster, then studied the hymnbook in his lap, tracing the gold letters on the cover with his finger. The prayer seemed to stretch on forever, and Tom sighed inwardly, wishing it would end so he could stand up and stretch his legs.  

Beside him, Sid sat perfectly still, his hands folded in his lap, his eyes closed in pious attention. Tom nudged him with his elbow, but Sid only frowned slightly and ignored him. Across the aisle, Becky Thatcher sat with her head bowed, her golden curls catching the sunlight streaming through the stained-glass windows. Tom’s heart gave a little leap at the sight of her, and for a moment, he forgot his boredom.  

The minister’s voice rose and fell in steady rhythm, calling down blessings upon the congregation, asking for guidance and mercy. Tom’s thoughts drifted to the pirate treasure he and Huck had vowed to find, to the secret cave where Injun Joe might still be hiding. The prayer became a distant hum, like the buzzing of bees on a summer afternoon.  

At last, the minister said, “Amen,” and the congregation echoed it with relief. Tom straightened up, glad to be free from the torment of sitting still. The choir began to sing, and the people rose to their feet, rustling their Sunday best as they turned to the hymnbooks. Tom mouthed the words without making a sound, his eyes darting around the room, searching for any sign of mischief to occupy his restless mind.  

Church was a trial to be endured, but at least it was nearly over. Soon he would be outside, running free under the wide blue sky, where sermons and prayers couldn’t reach him. And with that comforting thought, Tom endured the rest of the service, counting down the minutes until he could escape into the golden freedom of a St. Petersburg afternoon.

events.title: Monotonous Sermon and Tom's Fleeting Fascination
detailed_summary: The minister announced his sermon text and began a monotonous, prosaic argument, despite its themes of eternal damnation and the very few chosen for salvation, causing many congregants to doze off.
Tom, as was his habit, counted the sermon's pages, typically remembering little else about its content.
However, he experienced a brief flicker of interest when the minister described the millennial gathering where a lion and lamb would coexist peacefully under a child's guidance.
The profound meaning and moral of this spectacle were lost on Tom; he was instead captivated by the idea of being that prominent child, especially if the lion was tame.

Tom counted the pages of the sermon; after church he always knew how many pages there had been, but he seldom knew anything else about the discourse. However, this time he was really interested for a little while. The minister made a grand and moving picture of the assembling together of the world’s hosts at the millennium when the lion and the lamb should lie down together and a little child should lead them. But the pathos, the lesson, the moral of the great spectacle were lost upon the boy; he only thought of the conspicuousness of the principal character before the on-looking nations; his face lit with the thought, and he said to himself that he wished he could be that child, if it was a tame lion.

events.title: Tom's Pinchbug and the Poodle's Chaotic Interruption
detailed_summary: As the sermon continued its dry course, Tom's boredom intensified.
He retrieved a prized possession: a large black beetle with strong jaws, which he called a "pinchbug," kept in a percussion-cap box.
The beetle immediately bit Tom's finger, causing him to flick it into the aisle, where it landed on its back, struggling.
Tom longed to retrieve it, but it was out of reach; other disinterested congregants also noticed the beetle.
A stray poodle, looking melancholic and weary, wandered into the church.
The poodle spotted the beetle, its interest piqued. It cautiously approached, sniffed, and then began to playfully bat at the insect.
Eventually, the poodle lay down with the beetle between its paws, but then, growing drowsy, its chin touched the beetle, which bit it.
The poodle yelped sharply, flinging the beetle some distance away; Tom and other onlookers found this amusing.
Feeling resentful, the dog renewed its attack on the beetle, jumping and snapping at it.
Tiring of this, the poodle tried to entertain itself with a fly and an ant, but then, forgetting the beetle, accidentally sat on it.
A piercing yelp of agony followed as the poodle shot up the aisle, its cries echoing through the church.
It raced frantically around the building, past the altar and down the aisles, a furry blur of motion and distress.
Finally, the distraught dog leaped into its master's lap, who promptly threw it out of a window, its cries fading in the distance.

events.text_segment: Now he lapsed into suffering again, as the dry argument was resumed. Presently he bethought him of a treasure he had and got it out. It was a large black beetle with formidable jaws—a “pinchbug,” he called it. It was in a percussion-cap box. The first thing the beetle did was to take him by the finger. A natural fillip followed, the beetle went floundering into the aisle and lit on its back, and the hurt finger went into the boy’s mouth. The beetle lay there working its helpless legs, unable to turn over. Tom eyed it, and longed for it; but it was safe out of his reach. Other people uninterested in the sermon found relief in the beetle, and they eyed it too. Presently a vagrant poodle dog came idling along, sad at heart, lazy with the summer softness and the quiet, weary of captivity, sighing for change. He spied the beetle; the drooping tail lifted and wagged. He surveyed the prize; walked around it; smelt at it from a safe distance; walked around it again; grew bolder, and took a closer smell; then lifted his lip and made a gingerly snatch at it, just missing it; made another, and another; began to enjoy the diversion; subsided to his stomach with the beetle between his paws, and continued his experiments; grew weary at last, and then indifferent and absent-minded. His head nodded, and little by little his chin descended and touched the enemy, who seized it. There was a sharp yelp, a flirt of the poodle’s head, and the beetle fell a couple of yards away, and lit on its back once more. The neighboring spectators shook with a gentle inward joy, several faces went behind fans and hand-kerchiefs, and Tom was entirely happy. The dog looked foolish, and probably felt so; but there was resentment in his heart, too, and a craving for revenge. So he went to the beetle and began a wary attack on it again; jumping at it from every point of a circle, lighting with his fore-paws within an inch of the creature, making even closer snatches at it with his teeth, and jerking his head till his ears flapped again. But he grew tired once more, after a while; tried to amuse himself with a fly but found no relief; followed an ant around, with his nose close to the floor, and quickly wearied of that; yawned, sighed, forgot the beetle entirely, and sat down on it. Then there was a wild yelp of agony and the poodle went sailing up the aisle; the yelps continued, and so did the dog; he crossed the house in front of the altar; he flew down the other aisle; he crossed before the doors; he clamored up the home-stretch; his anguish grew with his progress, till presently he was but a woolly comet moving in its orbit with the gleam and the speed of light. At last the frantic sufferer sheered from its course, and sprang into its master’s lap; he flung it out of the window, and the voice of distress quickly thinned away and died in the distance.

events.text_segment:
Monday morning found Tom Sawyer miserable. Monday morning always found him so—because it began another week’s slow suffering in school. He generally began that day with wishing he had had no intervening holiday, it made the going into captivity and fetters again so much more odious.
Tom lay thinking. Presently it occurred to him that he wished he was sick; then he could stay home from school. Here was a vague possibility. He canvassed his system. No ailment was found, and he investigated again. This time he thought he could detect colicky symptoms, and he began to encourage them with considerable hope. But they soon grew feeble, and presently died wholly away. He reflected further. Suddenly he discovered something. One of his upper front teeth was loose. This was lucky; he was about to begin to groan, as a “starter,” as he called it, when it occurred to him that if he came into court with that argument, his aunt would pull it out, and that would hurt. So he thought he would hold the tooth in reserve for the present, and seek further. Nothing offered for some little time, and then he remembered hearing the doctor tell about a certain thing that laid up a patient for two or three weeks and threatened to make him lose a finger. So the boy eagerly drew his sore toe from under the sheet and held it up for inspection. But now he did not know the necessary symptoms. However, it seemed well worth while to chance it, so he fell to groaning with considerable spirit.

Monday morning found Tom Sawyer miserable. The bright sunshine streaming through his window only deepened his gloom, for it meant another week of school—another week of sitting still, reciting lessons, and enduring the stern gaze of Mr. Dobbins.  

He groaned and pulled the covers over his head, wishing he could stay in bed forever. But Aunt Polly’s sharp voice soon shattered his hopes. "Tom! Up with you, or you’ll be late for school again!"  

With a heavy sigh, he dragged himself out of bed, his bare feet shuffling across the wooden floor. The thought of school made his stomach twist. If only he could be like Huck Finn, free to wander the riverbanks and explore the woods! But no—today, he’d be trapped inside, memorizing dull facts and trying not to yawn too loudly.  

As he dressed, he glanced at the little treasures on his shelf—a piece of blue glass, a rusty knife, a dead frog—reminders of happier days. If only he could skip school and go fishing instead! But Aunt Polly would never allow it.  

Downstairs, breakfast was a quiet affair. Sid, his ever-perfect half-brother, ate neatly, while Tom pushed his food around his plate. "Ain’t you hungry?" Aunt Polly asked.  

"Reckon not," Tom muttered.  

She frowned but said nothing. Tom knew she saw through his misery but wouldn’t let him off so easily.  

With a final, longing look at the open window, he grabbed his books and trudged out the door, his heart as heavy as his steps. Another Monday, another prison sentence—unless, of course, he could dream up some grand escape.

Tom lay still, his heart pounding in his chest as he listened for any sign that his scheme had been discovered. The house was silent except for the faint creaking of the old beams settling in the night.

His cousin, always the tattletale, had no idea what had happened. Aunt Polly would be furious when she found out, but by then, it would be too late.

“Oh, auntie, I’m—”
“What’s the matter with you—what is the matter with you, child?”

The old lady made one end of the silk thread fast to Tom’s tooth with a loop and tied the other to the bedpost. Then she seized the chunk of fire and suddenly thrust it almost into the boy’s face. events.text_segment:
But all trials bring their compensations. As Tom wended to school after breakfast, he was the envy of every boy he met because the gap in his upper row of teeth enabled him to expectorate in a new and admirable way. He gathered quite a following of lads interested in the exhibition; and one that had cut his finger and had been a centre of fascination and homage up to this time, now found himself suddenly without an adherent, and shorn of his glory. His heart was heavy, and he said with a disdain which he did not feel that it wasn’t anything to spit like Tom Sawyer; but another boy said, “Sour grapes!” and he wandered away a dismantled hero.
Shortly Tom came upon the juvenile pariah of the village, Huckleberry Finn, son of the town drunkard. Huckleberry was cordially hated and dreaded by all the mothers of the town, because he was idle and lawless and vulgar and bad—and because all their children admired him so, and delighted in his forbidden society, and wished they dared to be like him. Tom was like the rest of the respectable boys, in that he envied Huckleberry his gaudy outcast condition, and was under strict orders not to play with him. So he played with him every time he got a chance. Huckleberry was always dressed in the cast-off clothes of full-grown men, and they were in perennial bloom and fluttering with rags. His hat was a vast ruin with a wide crescent lopped out of its brim; his coat, when he wore one, hung nearly to his heels and had the rearward buttons far down the back; but one suspender supported his trousers; the seat of the trousers bagged low and contained nothing, the fringed legs dragged in the dirt when not rolled up.
Huckleberry came and went, at his own free will. He slept on doorsteps in fine weather and in empty hogsheads in wet; he did not have to go to school or to church, or call any being master or obey anybody; he could go fishing or swimming when and where he chose, and stay as long as it suited him; nobody forbade him to fight; he could sit up as late as he pleased; he was always the first boy that went barefoot in the spring and the last to resume leather in the fall; he never had to wash, nor put on clean clothes; he could swear wonderfully. In a word, everything that goes to make life precious that boy had. So thought every harassed, hampered, respectable boy in St. Petersburg.

But all trials bring their compensations. As Tom Sawyer lay in bed that night, bruised and weary from the day’s misadventures, he couldn’t help but reflect on the strange turn of events. True, he had suffered the indignity of being punished for a crime he didn’t commit—whitewashing the fence had been his own clever scheme, after all—but in the end, it had earned him not only the admiration of his peers but a small fortune in traded treasures. The memory of the other boys begging for a turn with the brush brought a sly grin to his face.  

Then there was the matter of Becky Thatcher. His heart ached at the thought of her tears when he had accidentally revealed his past affection for Amy Lawrence. Yet, even that disaster had been softened by Becky’s forgiveness, and the way she had shyly slipped her hand into his during recess the next day. Tom had learned that sometimes, honesty—even when forced—could mend what deception had broken.  

And what of Injun Joe? The terror of the graveyard still haunted Tom’s dreams, but it had also made him a hero in the eyes of the town. The adults whispered about his bravery, and even Aunt Polly, who scolded him more often than not, had hugged him tight when she thought no one was looking. There was power in truth, Tom realized, even when it was frightening to tell.  

Even the loneliness he had felt when he ran away to Jackson’s Island had its silver lining. For those few days, he had been free—no school, no chores, just the river and the stars and the company of his friends. And when he returned, thinking himself forgotten, the sight of the entire town mourning him had filled him with a strange, guilty pride. He mattered to them. That was something.  

Life, Tom decided, was like a winding river—full of sharp turns and hidden dangers, but always moving forward. Every scrape, every punishment, every moment of fear or regret carried with it some small reward, if only he had the sense to look for it.  

With that thought, he turned over in bed, wincing slightly at his sore muscles, and closed his eyes. Tomorrow would bring new troubles, no doubt—but it would also bring new adventures, new chances to outsmart the world, and maybe even another glimpse of Becky’s golden hair in the sunlight.  

And that was enough.

events.title: Wart Cures, Witchcraft, and a Strategic Trade
detailed_summary: Tom greets Huckleberry, who responds in his characteristic carefree manner.
Tom inquires about what Huck is carrying, and Huck reveals it's a dead cat.
Huck explains he acquired the cat for curing warts.
Tom counters that spunk-water is a better cure, and describes a specific ritual involving going to a spunk-water stump in the woods at midnight and reciting an incantation.
Huck then shares his method for curing warts with a bean: splitting it, getting blood on one piece, burying it at a crossroads at midnight during a dark moon, and burning the rest.
Tom approves of Huck's bean method, adding his own incantation learned from Joe Harper.

Huck then details the dead cat method: take the cat to a graveyard around midnight when a wicked person has been buried, wait for devils to come for the body, then throw the cat after them while reciting a specific charm.
They discuss
old Mother Hopkins,
whom Huck confidently states is a witch, recounting how she supposedly witched his father after he tried to hit her with a rock.
Huck reveals he plans to try the dead cat cure that very night for
old Hoss Williams,
who was buried on Saturday, explaining that the charms wouldn't work until midnight, and devils don't work on Sundays.
Tom asks if he can join Huck, and they agree to signal each other by meowing.
Huck then shows Tom a tick he found in the woods.
After some back-and-forth, Tom offers his newly extracted tooth in exchange for the tick.
Huck inspects the tooth and the gap in Tom's mouth to confirm its authenticity, then agrees to the trade.
The boys separate, each feeling enriched by the transaction.

events.text_segment:
Tom hailed the romantic outcast:
“Hello, Huckleberry!”
“Hello yourself, and see how you like it.”
“What’s that you got?”
“Dead cat.”
“Lemme see him, Huck. My, he’s pretty stiff. Where’d you get him?”
“Bought him off’n a boy.”
“What did you give?”
“I give a blue ticket and a bladder that I got at the slaughter-house.”
“Where’d you get the blue ticket?”
“Bought it off’n Ben Rogers two weeks ago for a hoop-stick.”
“Say—what is dead cats good for, Huck?”
“Good for? Cure warts with.”
“No! Is that so? I know something that’s better.”
“I bet you don’t. What is it?”
“Why, spunk-water.”
“Spunk-water! I wouldn’t give a dern for spunk-water.”
“You wouldn’t, wouldn’t you? D’you ever try it?”
“No, I hain’t. But Bob Tanner did.”
“Who told you so!”
“Why, he told Jeff Thatcher, and Jeff told Johnny Baker, and Johnny told Jim Hollis, and Jim told Ben Rogers, and Ben told a nigger, and the nigger told me. There now!”
“Well, what of it? They’ll all lie. Leastways all but the nigger. I don’t know him. But I never see a nigger that wouldn’t lie. Shucks! Now you tell me how Bob Tanner done it, Huck.”
“Why, he took and dipped his hand in a rotten stump where the rain-water was.”
“In the daytime?”
“Certainly.”
“With his face to the stump?”
“Yes. Least I reckon so.”
“Did he say anything?”
“I don’t reckon he did. I don’t know.”
“Aha! Talk about trying to cure warts with spunk-water such a blame fool way as that! Why, that ain’t a-going to do any good. You got to go all by yourself, to the middle of the woods, where you know there’s a spunk-water stump, and just as it’s midnight you back up against the stump and jam your hand in and say:
‘Barley-corn, barley-corn, injun-meal shorts,
Spunk-water, spunk-water, swaller these warts,’
and then walk away quick, eleven steps, with your eyes shut, and then turn around three times and walk home without speaking to anybody. Because if you speak the charm’s busted.”
“Well, that sounds like a good way; but that ain’t the way Bob Tanner done.”
“No, sir, you can bet he didn’t, becuz he’s the wartiest boy in this town; and he wouldn’t have a wart on him if he’d knowed how to work spunk-water. I’ve took off thousands of warts off of my hands that way, Huck. I play with frogs so much that I’ve always got considerable many warts. Sometimes I take ’em off with a bean.”
“Yes, bean’s good. I’ve done that.”
“Have you? What’s your way?”
“You take and split the bean, and cut the wart so as to get some blood, and then you put the blood on one piece of the bean and take and dig a hole and bury it ’bout midnight at the crossroads in the dark of the moon, and then you burn up the rest of the bean. You see that piece that’s got the blood on it will keep drawing and drawing, trying to fetch the other piece to it, and so that helps the blood to draw the wart, and pretty soon off she comes.”
“Yes, that’s it, Huck—that’s it; though when you’re burying it if you say ‘Down bean; off wart; come no more to bother me!’ it’s better. That’s the way Joe Harper does, and he’s been nearly to Coonville and most everywheres. But say—how do you cure ’em with dead cats?”

Tom hailed the romantic outcast:  

“Hello, Huckleberry!”  

Huck Finn, the son of the town drunkard, was a boy envied by all the youth of St. Petersburg and dreaded by all their mothers. He was idle, lawless, vulgar, and bad—and yet every boy in the village secretly wished to be like him. Huck came and went as he pleased, slept wherever he chose, never had to wash or wear clean clothes, and could swear magnificently. In short, he possessed everything that makes life glorious to a boy.  

Tom, though far more respectable in the eyes of the grown-ups, admired Huck’s freedom. He had often longed to swap places with him, if only for a day.  

“What you got there?” Tom asked, eyeing the dead cat Huck swung carelessly by its tail.  

“Dead cat,” Huck replied. “Good for curing warts.”  

“How?”  

“You take it to the graveyard at midnight where somebody wicked’s been buried. When the devil comes to fetch ’em, you heave the cat after him and say, ‘Devil follow corpse, cat follow devil, warts follow cat—I’m done with ye!’ That’ll fetch any wart.”  

Tom considered this with deep interest. “You ever tried it?”  

“Not yet. But old Mother Hopkins told me.”  

“Well, I reckon it’s so, then. Say, Huck—let me go with you some night.”  

Huck scratched his head, considering. “I dunno. You ain’t afraid of ghosts, are you?”  

“’Course not!” Tom lied stoutly.  

“Well, all right. But you got to keep mum. And you got to bring a dead cat.”  

Tom agreed eagerly, and the two boys fell into step, discussing the finer points of wart-curing and other forbidden knowledge.  

“Where you bound now?” Tom asked.  

“Nowheres much. Just loafin’.”  

“Let’s go fishing.”  

“Ain’t got no hooks.”  

“I’ll lend you one.”  

Huck brightened. “All right. Where’s your line?”  

“In my pocket.”  

“We’ll need bait.”  

“I’ll dig some worms.”  

Huck nodded approvingly. Fishing was a noble pursuit, requiring neither school nor chores. The two boys set off toward the river, their bare feet kicking up dust in the summer heat.  

As they walked, Tom’s mind wandered to the grand schemes he was always concocting. “Huck, you ever think about being a pirate?”  

Huck spat thoughtfully. “What’s a pirate do?”  

“Oh, they take ships and bury treasure and fight with swords. They don’t answer to nobody.”  

Huck’s eyes gleamed. “That sounds bully. Where do you sign up?”  

Tom grinned. “We could be pirates ourselves. Right here on the Mississippi. Get a gang together, swear blood oaths, the whole works.”  

Huck was silent a moment, then said, “I’m in. But we’d need a hideout.”  

“Jackson’s Island! Nobody goes there.”  

The idea took root, and soon the boys were deep in plans for their pirate band. They would need provisions, weapons (sticks would do), and a proper flag. Tom’s imagination soared.  

By the time they reached the riverbank, their futures as terror of the high seas seemed assured. Tom dug for worms while Huck fashioned hooks from bent pins. The sun beat down, the river murmured, and for a little while, the world belonged entirely to them.  

Later, as they dangled their lines in the water, Huck said, “Tom, you ever run away?”  

“Sometimes. But Aunt Polly always fetches me back.”  

Huck sighed. “I run off for good once. Slept in the woods, ate berries. Nobody missed me.”  

Tom felt a pang of something like envy. Huck’s freedom was absolute. No rules, no school, no nagging.  

“Must be nice,” he said.  

Huck shrugged. “Gets lonesome.”  

Tom couldn’t imagine Huck lonely. He seemed as self-sufficient as a wild creature. But there was a shadow in Huck’s eyes that made Tom think maybe even outlaws needed company sometimes.  

They fished in companionable silence until the sun began to dip. Then, with their meager catch (two small sunfish and a perch), they parted ways—Huck to wherever he laid his head that night, Tom to Aunt Polly’s and supper.  

As he walked home, Tom thought about pirates and dead cats and the wide, wild world beyond St. Petersburg. One day, he vowed, he and Huck would sail away and never come back.  

But for now, there was supper—and tomorrow, another adventure.

events.title: Tom's Calculated Tardiness and Shocking Confession at School
detailed_summary: Tom arrives at the small, isolated schoolhouse, adopting an air of having hurried with honest speed.
He hangs his hat and settles into his seat with business-like alacrity, which rouses the master from his doze.
The master addresses Tom by his full name,
Thomas Sawyer,
a sign of impending trouble.
When questioned about his tardiness, Tom is on the verge of lying.
However, he spots two long yellow pigtails belonging to a girl he recognizes with an
electric sympathy of love
; by her side is the only vacant place on the girls' side of the room.
Tom promptly and audaciously confesses,
I stopped to talk with Huckleberry Finn!
The master is momentarily paralyzed by shock, and the usual hum of study in the classroom ceases as pupils stare, wondering if Tom has lost his mind.
The master, still disbelieving, asks Tom to repeat his statement.
Tom confirms his words without hesitation.

When Tom reached the little isolated frame school-house, he strode in briskly, with the manner of one who had come with all honest speed. He hung his hat on a peg and flung himself into his seat with business-like alacrity. The master, throned on high in his great splint-bottom arm-chair, was dozing, lulled by the drowsy hum of study. The interruption roused him.
“Thomas Sawyer!”
Tom knew that when his name was pronounced in full, it meant trouble.
“Sir!”
“Come up here. Now, sir, why are you late again, as usual?”
Tom was about to take refuge in a lie, when he saw two long tails of yellow hair hanging down a back that he recognized by the electric sympathy of love; and by that form was the only vacant place on the girls’ side of the school-house. He instantly said:
“I stopped to talk with Huckleberry Finn!”
The master’s pulse stood still, and he stared helplessly. The buzz of study ceased. The pupils wondered if this foolhardy boy had lost his mind. The master said:
“You—you did what?”
“Stopped to talk with Huckleberry Finn.”
There was no mistaking the words.

“Thomas Sawyer, this is the most astounding confession I have ever listened to. No mere ferule will answer for this offence. Take off your jacket.”
The master’s arm performed until it was tired and the stock of switches notably diminished. Then the order followed:
“Now, sir, go and sit with the girls! And let this be a warning to you.”
The titter that rippled around the room appeared to abash the boy, but in reality that result was caused rather more by his worshipful awe of his unknown idol and the dread pleasure that lay in his high good fortune. He sat down upon the end of the pine bench and the girl hitched herself away from him with a toss of her head. Nudges and winks and whispers traversed the room, but Tom sat still, with his arms upon the long, low desk before him, and seemed to study his book.
By and by attention ceased from him, and the accustomed school murmur rose upon the dull air once more. Presently the boy began to steal furtive glances at the girl. She observed it, “made a mouth” at him and gave him the back of her head for the space of a minute. When she cautiously faced around again, a peach lay before her. She thrust it away. Tom gently put it back. She thrust it away again, but with less animosity. Tom patiently returned it to its place. Then she let it remain. Tom scrawled on his slate, “Please take it—I got more.” The girl glanced at the words, but made no sign. Now the boy began to draw something on the slate, hiding his work with his left hand. For a time the girl refused to notice; but her human curiosity presently began to manifest itself by hardly perceptible signs. The boy worked on, apparently unconscious. The girl made a sort of non-committal attempt to see, but the boy did not betray that he was aware of it. At last she gave in and hesitatingly whispered:
“Let me see it.”
Tom partly uncovered a dismal caricature of a house with two gable ends to it and a corkscrew of smoke issuing from the chimney. Then the girl’s interest began to fasten itself upon the work and she forgot everything else. When it was finished, she gazed a moment, then whispered:
“It’s nice—make a man.”
The artist erected a man in the front yard, that resembled a derrick. He could have stepped over the house; but the girl was not hypercritical; she was satisfied with the monster, and whispered:
“It’s a beautiful man—now make me coming along.”
Tom drew an hour-glass with a full moon and straw limbs to it and armed the spreading fingers with a portentous fan. The girl said:
“It’s ever so nice—I wish I could draw.”
“It’s easy,” whispered Tom, “I’ll learn you.”
“Oh, will you? When?”
“At noon. Do you go home to dinner?”
“I’ll stay if you will.”
“Good—that’s a whack. What’s your name?”
“Becky Thatcher. What’s yours? Oh, I know. It’s Thomas Sawyer.”
“That’s the name they lick me by. I’m Tom when I’m good. You call me Tom, will you?”
“Yes.”
Now Tom began to scrawl something on the slate, hiding the words from the girl. But she was not backward this time. She begged to see. Tom said:
“Oh, it ain’t anything.”
“Yes it is.”
“No it ain’t. You don’t want to see.”
“Yes I do, indeed I do. Please let me.”
“You’ll tell.”
“No I won’t—deed and deed and double deed won’t.”
“You won’t tell anybody at all? Ever, as long as you live?”
“No, I won’t ever tell anybody. Now let me.”
“Oh, you don’t want to see!”
“Now that you treat me so, I will see.” And she put her small hand upon his and a little scuffle ensued, Tom pretending to resist in earnest but letting his hand slip by degrees till these words were revealed: “I love you.”
“Oh, you bad thing!” And she hit his hand a smart rap, but reddened and looked pleased, nevertheless.

She pressed her lips together, fighting the smile that threatened to break through. "Don’t you sass me, young man. What you did was downright dishonest."  

"But I got the fence whitewashed, didn’t I?" Tom pointed out, unable to resist a grin. "Three coats, just like you wanted. And I didn’t make ’em do it—they *wanted* to. Ben Rogers said it was an honor!"  

Aunt Polly shook her head, but the corners of her mouth twitched. "Oh, go on with you. I ought to make you give back every last marble."  

Tom’s face fell. "Aw, Aunt Polly, that ain’t fair! A deal’s a deal!"  

She folded her arms. "And what about the poor boys who think they were doing you a favor?"  

Tom scratched his head, considering this. "Well… I reckon I could let ’em in on my next scheme. Share the profits, so to speak."  

Aunt Polly’s eyebrows shot up. "Next scheme?"  

Tom realized his mistake too late. "I mean—uh—next *chore*. Like… splitting kindling. Or fetching water."  

She sighed again, but this time it was fond. "Tom Sawyer, you’re a rascal and no mistake. But I suppose there’s no harm done this time. Just see to it you don’t go swindling the whole town before you’re grown."  

Tom brightened immediately. "Yes, ma’am! I’ll be as honest as the day is long!"  

Aunt Polly snorted. "I’ll believe that when I see it. Now go on, get out from underfoot. And take that dead rat with you—I won’t have it stinking up my kitchen."  

Tom scooped up his treasures and bolted for the door before she could change her mind. Outside, the golden afternoon sunlight spilled over the sleepy town of St. Petersburg, and the world was once again ripe for adventure.  

Huck Finn was waiting by the picket fence, idly tossing a knife into the dirt. "Well?" he drawled. "She tan your hide?"  

Tom grinned, holding up his loot. "Nope. And I got to keep it all."  

Huck whistled low. "Danged if you ain’t the slickest feller in Missouri."  

Tom puffed out his chest. "Just you wait, Huck. This is only the beginning. Why, with a mind like mine, there ain’t nothing we can’t pull off."  

And with that, the two boys sauntered off down the dusty road, their pockets jingling with ill-gotten gains and their heads full of grand plans. Somewhere in the distance, a steamboat whistle blew, carrying the promise of new escapades—and no doubt, new trouble—just around the bend.  

For Tom Sawyer, life was good.

detailed_summary: Tom struggles to concentrate on his studies, feeling increasingly restless as his mind wanders.

events.text_segment: The harder Tom tried to fasten his mind on his book, the more his ideas wandered. So at last, with a sigh and a yawn, he gave it up. It seemed to him that the noon recess would never come. The air was utterly dead. There was not a breath stirring. It was the sleepiest of sleepy days. The drowsing murmur of the five and twenty studying scholars soothed the soul like the spell that is in the murmur of bees. Away off in the flaming sunshine, Cardiff Hill lifted its soft green sides through a shimmering veil of heat, tinted with the purple of distance; a few birds floated on lazy wing high in the air; no other living thing was visible but some cows, and they were asleep. Tom’s heart ached to be free, or else to have something of interest to do to pass the dreary time. His hand wandered into his pocket and his face lit up with a glow of gratitude that was prayer, though he did not know it. Then furtively the percussion-cap box came out. He released the tick and put him on the long flat desk. The creature probably glowed with a gratitude that amounted to prayer, too, at this moment, but it was premature: for when he started thankfully to travel off, Tom turned him aside with a pin and made him take a new direction.

For a while, luck favors Joe, who skillfully manages to keep the tick on his side despite its attempts to escape, frustrating Tom whose fingers twitch in anticipation.
Unable to bear it any longer, Tom succumbs to temptation and uses his pin to interfere while the tick is on Joe's side.
Joe immediately becomes angry, accusing Tom of unfair play.
Tom tries to minimize his action, but Joe insists he leave the tick alone.
The argument escalates, with Tom claiming his right to do as he pleases with his own tick, regardless of the rules.

“Now,” said he, “as long as he is on your side you can stir him up and I’ll let him alone; but if you let him get away and get on my side, you’re to leave him alone as long as I can keep him from crossing over.”
“All right, go ahead; start him up.”
The tick escaped from Tom, presently, and crossed the equator. Joe harassed him awhile, and then he got away and crossed back again. This change of base occurred often. While one boy was worrying the tick with absorbing interest, the other would look on with interest as strong, the two heads bowed together over the slate, and the two souls dead to all things else. At last luck seemed to settle and abide with Joe. The tick tried this, that, and the other course, and got as excited and as anxious as the boys themselves, but time and again just as he would have victory in his very grasp, so to speak, and Tom’s fingers would be twitching to begin, Joe’s pin would deftly head him off, and keep possession. At last Tom could stand it no longer. The temptation was too strong. So he reached out and lent a hand with his pin. Joe was angry in a moment. Said he:
“Tom, you let him alone.”
“I only just want to stir him up a little, Joe.”
“No, sir, it ain’t fair; you just let him alone.”
“Blame it, I ain’t going to stir him much.”
“Let him alone, I tell you.”
“I won’t!”
“You shall—he’s on my side of the line.”
“Look here, Joe Harper, whose is that tick?”
“I don’t care whose tick he is—he’s on my side of the line, and you sha’n’t touch him.”
“Well, I’ll just bet I will, though. He’s my tick and I’ll do what I blame please with him, or die!”

So the one went off with one group of scholars, and the other with another. In a little while the two met at the bottom of the lane, and when they reached the school they had it all to themselves. Then they sat together, with a slate before them, and Tom gave Becky the pencil and held her hand in his, guiding it, and so created another surprising house. When the interest in art began to wane, the two fell to talking. Tom was swimming in bliss. He said:
“Do you love rats?”
“No! I hate them!”
“Well, I do, too—live ones. But I mean dead ones, to swing round your head with a string.”
“No, I don’t care for rats much, anyway. What I like is chewing-gum.”
“Oh, I should say so! I wish I had some now.”
“Do you? I’ve got some. I’ll let you chew it awhile, but you must give it back to me.”
That was agreeable, so they chewed it turn about, and dangled their legs against the bench in excess of contentment.
“Was you ever at a circus?” said Tom.
“Yes, and my pa’s going to take me again some time, if I’m good.”
“I been to the circus three or four times—lots of times. Church ain’t shucks to a circus. There’s things going on at a circus all the time. I’m going to be a clown in a circus when I grow up.”
“Oh, are you! That will be nice. They’re so lovely, all spotted up.”
“Yes, that’s so. And they get slathers of money—most a dollar a day, Ben Rogers says. Say, Becky, was you ever engaged?”
“What’s that?”
“Why, engaged to be married.”
“No.”
“Would you like to?”
“I reckon so. I don’t know. What is it like?”
“Like? Why it ain’t like anything. You only just tell a boy you won’t ever have anybody but him, ever ever ever, and then you kiss and that’s all. Anybody can do it.”

events.text_segment: Tom dodged hither and thither through lanes until he was well out of the track of returning scholars, and then fell into a moody jog. He crossed a small “branch” two or three times, because of a prevailing juvenile superstition that to cross water baffled pursuit. Half an hour later he was disappearing behind the Douglas mansion on the summit of Cardiff Hill, and the school-house was hardly distinguishable away off in the valley behind him. He entered a dense wood, picked his pathless way to the centre of it, and sat down on a mossy spot under a spreading oak. There was not even a zephyr stirring; the dead noonday heat had even stilled the songs of the birds; nature lay in a trance that was broken by no sound but the occasional far-off hammering of a wood-pecker, and this seemed to render the pervading silence and sense of loneliness the more profound. The boy’s soul was steeped in melancholy; his feelings were in happy accord with his surroundings. He sat long with his elbows on his knees and his chin in his hands, meditating. It seemed to him that life was but a trouble, at best, and he more than half envied Jimmy Hodges, so lately released; it must be very peaceful, he thought, to lie and slumber and dream forever and ever, with the wind whispering through the trees and caressing the grass and the flowers over the grave, and nothing to bother and grieve about, ever any more. If he only had a clean Sunday-school record he could be willing to go, and be done with it all. Now as to this girl. What had he done? Nothing. He had meant the best in the world, and been treated like a dog—like a very dog. She would be sorry some day—maybe when it was too late. Ah, if he could only die temporarily!

He crossed a small "branch" two or three times, because of a prevailing juvenile superstition that to cross water baffled pursuit. Half an hour later he was disappearing behind the Douglas mansion on the height, and the schoolhouse was hardly distinguishable away off in the valley behind him. He entered a dense wood, picked his pathless way to the centre of it, and sat down on a mossy spot under a spreading oak. There was not even a zephyr stirring; the dead noonday heat had even stilled the songs of the birds; nature lay in a trance that was broken by no sound but the occasional far-off hammering of a woodpecker, and this seemed to render the pervading silence and sense of loneliness the more profound. The boy's soul was steeped in melancholy; his feelings were in happy accord with his surroundings. He sat long with his elbows on his knees and his chin in his hands, meditating. It seemed to him that life was but a trouble, at best, and he more than half envied Jimmy Hodges, so lately released; it must be very peaceful, he thought, to lie and slumber and dream forever and ever, with the wind whispering through the trees and caressing the grass and the flowers over the grave, and nothing to bother and grieve about, ever any more. If he only had a clean Sunday-school record he could be willing to go, and be done with it all. Now as to this girl. What had he done? Nothing. He had meant the best in the world, and been treated like a dog—like a very dog. She would be sorry some day—maybe when it was too late. Ah, if he could only die *temporarily*!

But the elastic heart of youth cannot be compressed into one constrained shape long at a time. Tom Sawyer soon grew weary of the dull routine of school and the stern discipline of Aunt Polly. His restless spirit longed for adventure, for the freedom of the open fields and the whispering woods along the Mississippi.  

One bright morning, as the sun poured golden light over the sleepy town of St. Petersburg, Tom could bear it no longer. With a sly grin, he slipped away from his chores, his pockets jingling with a few stolen marbles and a piece of chalk—tools of mischief waiting to be put to use. There, he met his faithful comrade, Huckleberry Finn, the outcast boy whose bare feet and ragged clothes were badges of his untamed freedom. Together, they hatched a plan—a grand scheme that would shake the town and etch their names into the legends of boyhood.  

That afternoon, they vanished into the woods, pretending to be pirates, explorers, and outlaws. They built a makeshift raft, declared themselves captains of the Mississippi, and swore oaths of loyalty under the shade of an ancient oak. events.title: The Failed Marble Superstition and Witchcraft Accusation
detailed_summary: Having settled on his future as a pirate, Tom decided he would abscond from home the very next morning.
He immediately began preparations by attempting to gather his 'resources.'
He started digging with his Barlow knife under one end of a nearby rotten log.
He soon hit wood that sounded hollow, put his hand into the space, and recited an incantation.
After clearing away the dirt, he found a pine shingle covering a small, neatly constructed 'treasure-house' also made of shingles.
Inside, he discovered only a single marble, which left him utterly astonished.
This finding was a significant blow because a cherished superstition—that burying a marble with specific rituals would cause all of one's lost marbles to gather there—had failed.
Tom's foundational belief in such superstitions was severely shaken, as he had only ever heard of this particular one succeeding.
He did not consider that his own previous attempts might have failed because he couldn't relocate the hiding places afterward.
He puzzled over this failure and ultimately concluded that a witch must have interfered and nullified the charm.
To verify his theory, he located a small, funnel-shaped depression in a sandy area, a sign of a doodle-bug's lair.
He lay down and called to the doodle-bug, asking it to reveal what he wanted to know.
When a small black bug briefly emerged and then quickly retreated, Tom took this as confirmation that a witch was responsible, believing the bug was too scared to tell the truth.
Recognizing the futility of confronting witches, he abandoned this line of investigation with a sense of discouragement.

events.text_segment:
Yes, it was settled; his career was determined. He would run away from home and enter upon it. He would start the very next morning. Therefore he must now begin to get ready. He would collect his resources together. He went to a rotten log near at hand and began to dig under one end of it with his Barlow knife. He soon struck wood that sounded hollow. He put his hand there and uttered this incantation impressively:
“What hasn’t come here, come! What’s here, stay here!”
Then he scraped away the dirt, and exposed a pine shingle. He took it up and disclosed a shapely little treasure-house whose bottom and sides were of shingles. In it lay a marble. Tom’s astonishment was boundless! He scratched his head with a perplexed air, and said:
“Well, that beats anything!”
Then he tossed the marble away pettishly, and stood cogitating. The truth was, that a superstition of his had failed, here, which he and all his comrades had always looked upon as infallible. If you buried a marble with certain necessary incantations, and left it alone a fortnight, and then opened the place with the incantation he had just used, you would find that all the marbles you had ever lost had gathered themselves together there, meantime, no matter how widely they had been separated. But now, this thing had actually and unquestionably failed. Tom’s whole structure of faith was shaken to its foundations. He had many a time heard of this thing succeeding but never of its failing before. It did not occur to him that he had tried it several times before, himself, but could never find the hiding-places afterward. He puzzled over the matter some time, and finally decided that some witch had interfered and broken the charm. He thought he would satisfy himself on that point; so he searched around till he found a small sandy spot with a little funnel-shaped depression in it. He laid himself down and put his mouth close to this depression and called—
“Doodle-bug, doodle-bug, tell me what I want to know! Doodle-bug, doodle-bug, tell me what I want to know!”
The sand began to work, and presently a small black bug appeared for a second and then darted under again in a fright.
“He dasn’t tell! So it was a witch that done it. I just knowed it.”
He well knew the futility of trying to contend against witches, so he gave up discouraged.

Yes, it was settled; his career was determined. Tom Sawyer, the mischievous and imaginative boy of St. Petersburg, had finally made up his mind. After all his grand adventures—playing pirate on Jackson’s Island, witnessing a murder in the graveyard, and uncovering Injun Joe’s treasure—he had decided what he wanted to be when he grew up.  

Tom sat on the fence outside his Aunt Polly’s house, swinging his legs and gazing at the Mississippi River as the sun dipped below the horizon. The golden light danced on the water, and in that moment, he knew. He would be a riverboat pilot, just like the ones he admired—bold, free, and always on the move.  

The idea had been growing in his mind ever since he and Huck Finn had watched the great steamboats churn up the river, their smokestacks belching black clouds into the sky. The pilots stood tall in their wheelhouses, commanding the mighty vessels with ease, their voices ringing out over the water. To Tom, they were the kings of the river, untouchable and grand.  

Aunt Polly would surely fret over his choice—she had always hoped he’d settle into something respectable, like a lawyer or a storekeeper. But Tom couldn’t imagine anything duller. The river called to him, whispering promises of adventure and escape.  

Huck, of course, approved wholeheartedly. "Why, Tom, that’s the finest notion yet!" he had declared when Tom shared his plan. "You’ll see the whole country, and nobody to tell you what to do!"

He’d learn the currents, memorize every bend and sandbar, and become the most famous pilot on the Mississippi. For Tom Sawyer, the greatest adventure of all was just beginning.

events.title: Recovering the Lost Marble and Responding to the Call to Play
detailed_summary: Despite his discouragement over the supposed witchcraft, Tom decided he wanted to retrieve the marble he had earlier thrown away in a fit of pique.
He searched for it diligently but could not find it.
He then returned to the location of his 'treasure-house' and carefully positioned himself as he had been when he tossed the marble.
Taking another marble from his pocket, he threw it in the same manner, uttering an instruction for it to find its 'brother.'
After two more attempts, the third toss was successful; the second marble landed within a foot of the first, lost one.
Precisely at this moment, the distant sound of a toy tin trumpet drifted through the forest.

Tom reacted instantly: he shed his jacket and trousers, repurposed a suspender as a belt, and retrieved a hidden cache of play items—a rudimentary bow and arrow, a lath sword, and a tin trumpet—from behind the rotten log.
Within moments, he had armed himself with these items and dashed off, barelegged, his shirt flapping as he ran.

But it occurred to him that he might as well have the marble he had just thrown away, and therefore he went and made a patient search for it. But he could not find it. Now he went back to his treasure-house and carefully placed himself just as he had been standing when he tossed the marble away; then he took another marble from his pocket and tossed it in the same way, saying:
“Brother, go find your brother!”
He watched where it stopped, and went there and looked. But it must have fallen short or gone too far; so he tried twice more. The last repetition was successful. The two marbles lay within a foot of each other.
Just here the blast of a toy tin trumpet came faintly down the green aisles of the forest. Tom flung off his jacket and trousers, turned a suspender into a belt, raked away some brush behind the rotten log, disclosing a rude bow and arrow, a lath sword and a tin trumpet, and in a moment had seized these things and bounded away, barelegged, with fluttering shirt.

He crawled on hands and knees through the dust, squinting against the afternoon sun as he sifted through the dry grass.  

Just as he was about to give up, his fingers brushed against the smooth, round surface. A grin spread across his face—victory! But then he heard a familiar laugh behind him. It was Joe Harper, watching with amusement.  

"Lookin’ for somethin’, Tom?" Joe teased.  

Tom stood up quickly, dusting off his trousers. "Nothin’ much," he said, trying to sound careless. "Just checkin’ the ground for—uh—treasure."  

Joe smirked. "Sure, Tom. Sure."  

With a shrug, Tom pocketed the marble and sauntered off, already plotting his next adventure.

events.title: The Imaginative Enactment of Robin Hood with Joe Harper
detailed_summary: Tom paused his run under a large elm tree, blew an answering call on his tin trumpet, and then cautiously surveyed his surroundings.
He issued a command to an imaginary band of followers, instructing them to remain concealed until he signaled.
Joe Harper then appeared, similarly attired in makeshift costume and elaborately armed for their game.
Tom, in character, challenged Joe's unauthorized presence in 'Sherwood Forest.'
The boys began to enact a scene, reciting dialogue 'by the book' from memory, with Tom prompting Joe when he fumbled his lines.
Tom declared himself as Robin Hood, and Joe, playing Guy of Guisborne, readily accepted the challenge to a duel.
They put down their other playthings, adopted fencing stances, and commenced a serious and deliberate sword fight with their wooden lath swords, following a pattern of 'two up and two down' moves.
After some initial sparring, Tom encouraged Joe to fight with more energy.
During their duel, Tom insisted that Joe must fall, as dictated by the narrative of their story.
Joe initially protested but conceded when Tom referenced the book, which described Guy of Guisborne's demise at Robin Hood's hand, and allowed Tom to strike him in the back.
After being 'defeated,' Joe stood up and argued that it was only fair for him to get a chance to 'kill' Tom.
Tom countered that such a turn of events was not part of the established story.

They reached a compromise: Joe could play the role of Friar Tuck or Much the Miller's son and engage Tom with a quarter-staff, or alternatively, Tom would portray the Sheriff of Nottingham, allowing Joe, as Robin Hood, to defeat him.
These agreed-upon adventures were then acted out by the boys.
Subsequently, Tom reverted to his role as Robin Hood and, through a scenario involving a 'treacherous nun,' dramatically 'bled his strength away' from a neglected wound.
Finally, Joe, embodying a collective of grieving outlaws, mournfully carried Tom forth, placing his bow in his weakened hands.
Tom then uttered a dying wish: 'Where this arrow falls, there bury poor Robin Hood under the greenwood tree.'
He shot the arrow and fell back as if dead, but his performance was comically ruined when he landed on a nettle, causing him to spring up with an agility unbefitting a corpse.

“Hold, my merry men! Keep hid till I blow.”
Now appeared Joe Harper, as airily clad and elaborately armed as Tom. Tom called:
“Hold! Who comes here into Sherwood Forest without my pass?”
“Guy of Guisborne wants no man’s pass. Who art thou that—that—”
“Dares to hold such language,” said Tom, prompting—for they talked “by the book,” from memory.
“Who art thou that dares to hold such language?”
“I, indeed! I am Robin Hood, as thy caitiff carcase soon shall know.”
“Then art thou indeed that famous outlaw? Right gladly will I dispute with thee the passes of the merry wood. Have at thee!”
They took their lath swords, dumped their other traps on the ground, struck a fencing attitude, foot to foot, and began a grave, careful combat, “two up and two down.” Presently Tom said:
“Now, if you’ve got the hang, go it lively!”
So they “went it lively,” panting and perspiring with the work. By and by Tom shouted:
“Fall! fall! Why don’t you fall?”
“I sha’n’t! Why don’t you fall yourself? You’re getting the worst of it.”
“Why, that ain’t anything. I can’t fall; that ain’t the way it is in the book. The book says, ‘Then with one back-handed stroke he slew poor Guy of Guisborne.’ You’re to turn around and let me hit you in the back.”
There was no getting around the authorities, so Joe turned, received the whack and fell.
“Now,” said Joe, getting up, “you got to let me kill you. That’s fair.”
“Why, I can’t do that, it ain’t in the book.”
“Well, it’s blamed mean—that’s all.”
“Well, say, Joe, you can be Friar Tuck or Much the miller’s son, and lam me with a quarter-staff; or I’ll be the Sheriff of Nottingham and you be Robin Hood a little while and kill me.”
This was satisfactory, and so these adventures were carried out. Then Tom became Robin Hood again, and was allowed by the treacherous nun to bleed his strength away through his neglected wound. And at last Joe, representing a whole tribe of weeping outlaws, dragged him sadly forth, gave his bow into his feeble hands, and Tom said, “Where this arrow falls, there bury poor Robin Hood under the greenwood tree.” Then he shot the arrow and fell back and would have died, but he lit on a nettle and sprang up too gaily for a corpse.

He presently halted under a great elm, blew an answering blast, and then began to tiptoe and look warily out, this way and that. The woods were alive with the rustling of leaves and the distant calls of birds, but no human sound reached his ears. Tom’s heart pounded with excitement—this was the thrill of adventure he had longed for.  

Crouching low, he crept forward, his bare feet silent on the soft earth. Every shadow seemed to hide a lurking danger, every whisper of the wind a secret message. He was deep in enemy territory now—or so he imagined in his game of pirates and robbers.  

Suddenly, a twig snapped behind him. Tom froze, his breath catching in his throat. Slowly, he turned his head, half-expecting to see the fierce gaze of an outlaw or the glint of a pirate’s cutlass. Instead, a squirrel darted up the trunk of a nearby oak, chattering indignantly at the intruder. Tom let out a quiet laugh, his tension easing.  

But the game was far from over. He pressed on, determined to uncover the hidden treasure—or at least the secret hideout of his imaginary foes. The sun filtered through the thick canopy above, casting shifting patterns of light and shadow on the forest floor. It was the perfect setting for a grand adventure.  

Then, from the distance, came the faintest echo of a whistle—the signal. Tom’s eyes lit up. It was Joe Harper, his fellow conspirator in this afternoon’s escapade. Tom responded with two short whistles, their prearranged code. Moments later, Joe emerged from behind a thicket, his face smudged with dirt and his straw hat askew.  

“Any sign of ’em?” Joe whispered, his voice barely audible.  

Tom shook his head. “Nary a one. Reckon they’ve gone deeper into the woods.”  

Joe grinned. “Then we’ll track ’em down!”  

With renewed vigor, the two boys pressed forward, their imaginations transforming the quiet Missouri woods into a treacherous wilderness filled with danger and glory. The afternoon stretched before them, endless with possibility.  

For Tom Sawyer, there was no greater joy than this—the thrill of the unknown, the freedom of the wild, and the company of a trusted friend. The real world could wait; today belonged to adventure.

events.title: The Boys' Nostalgic Lament for the Age of Outlaws
detailed_summary: After concluding their imaginative play, Tom and Joe put their regular clothes back on.

They mutually declared that they would value a single year living as outlaws in Sherwood Forest more highly than a lifetime term as President of the United States.

events.title: Tom's Restless Wait and Nocturnal Rendezvous

The passage of time felt incredibly slow to him, heightening his impatience.
He was careful not to disturb Sid, so he remained still despite his nervousness.
The quietness of the night was gradually punctuated by distinct, unsettling sounds.

A muffled snore came from Aunt Polly's room.
An elusive cricket's chirping and the ominous ticking of a death-watch beetle in the wall intensified his dread, as the latter was believed to signify an impending death.
A distant dog's howl, answered by another even further away, added to his anguish.
Feeling that time had stopped, he began to drift off to sleep just before eleven.

He quickly dressed, exited through the window, and stealthily made his way across the roof.

events.text_segment: At half-past nine, that night, Tom and Sid were sent to bed, as usual. They said their prayers, and Sid was soon asleep. Tom lay awake and waited, in restless impatience. When it seemed to him that it must be nearly daylight, he heard the clock strike ten! This was despair. He would have tossed and fidgeted, as his nerves demanded, but he was afraid he might wake Sid. So he lay still, and stared up into the dark. Everything was dismally still. By and by, out of the stillness, little, scarcely perceptible noises began to emphasize themselves. The ticking of the clock began to bring itself into notice. Old beams began to crack mysteriously. The stairs creaked faintly. Evidently spirits were abroad. A measured, muffled snore issued from Aunt Polly’s chamber. And now the tiresome chirping of a cricket that no human ingenuity could locate, began. Next the ghastly ticking of a death-watch in the wall at the bed’s head made Tom shudder—it meant that somebody’s days were numbered. Then the howl of a far-off dog rose on the night air, and was answered by a fainter howl from a remoter distance. Tom was in an agony. At last he was satisfied that time had ceased and eternity begun; he began to doze, in spite of himself; the clock chimed eleven, but he did not hear it. And then there came, mingling with his half-formed dreams, a most melancholy caterwauling. The raising of a neighboring window disturbed him. A cry of “Scat! you devil!” and the crash of an empty bottle against the back of his aunt’s woodshed brought him wide awake, and a single minute later he was dressed and out of the window and creeping along the roof of the “ell” on all fours. He “meow’d” with caution once or twice, as he went; then jumped to the roof of the woodshed and thence to the ground. Huckleberry Finn was there, with his dead cat. The boys moved off and disappeared in the gloom. At the end of half an hour they were wading through the tall grass of the graveyard.

At half-past nine, that night, Tom and Sid were sent to bed, as usual. Sid fell asleep almost at once, his quiet breathing filling the small, moonlit room. But Tom lay wide awake, his mind buzzing with restless energy. The events of the day—playing hooky, whitewashing the fence, trading treasures with his friends—all swirled in his head like leaves caught in a whirlwind.  

He turned onto his side, staring at the patch of moonlight on the floor. Outside, the crickets chirped, and an occasional owl hooted in the distance. The familiar sounds of St. Petersburg at night usually lulled him to sleep, but tonight, they only sharpened his senses. He couldn’t shake the thrill of his latest scheme—the secret plan he and Huck Finn had hatched earlier that evening.  

A slow grin spread across Tom’s face as he remembered their whispered conversation by the graveyard fence. Midnight. That was the hour they’d agreed upon. He glanced at the clock on the mantel, its ticking unnaturally loud in the stillness. Still two hours to go.  

Tom sighed and flopped onto his back, kicking the sheets in frustration. Sid stirred slightly but didn’t wake. For a moment, Tom considered giving up and surrendering to sleep. But then he imagined Huck waiting for him under the stars, the two of them creeping through the shadows like pirates on a daring raid. The thought sent a shiver of excitement down his spine.  

Quietly, he slipped out of bed and tiptoed to the window. The cool night air brushed his face as he peered into the darkness. Somewhere out there, adventure waited—and Tom Sawyer was never one to let a little thing like bedtime stand in his way.

events.title: Arrival and Somber Atmosphere of the Graveyard
detailed_summary: The narrative describes the graveyard as typical of the old West, situated on a hill some distance from the village.
It was enclosed by a dilapidated board fence that was unstable and leaning in various directions.
The entire area was overgrown with rank grass and weeds.
Old graves were sunken, and there were no proper tombstones.
Instead, round-topped, decaying wooden markers, many askew, stood over the graves, their inscriptions largely illegible.
A faint wind rustling through the trees made Tom imagine it was the spirits of the deceased complaining about their presence.
The boys spoke infrequently and in hushed tones, feeling overwhelmed by the location's solemnity and silence.
They located the recently disturbed grave they were looking for and concealed themselves near three large elm trees close to it.

events.text_segment:
It was a graveyard of the old-fashioned Western kind. It was on a hill, about a mile and a half from the village. It had a crazy board fence around it, which leaned inward in places, and outward the rest of the time, but stood upright nowhere. Grass and weeds grew rank over the whole cemetery. All the old graves were sunken in, there was not a tombstone on the place; round-topped, worm-eaten boards staggered over the graves, leaning for support and finding none. “Sacred to the memory of” So-and-So had been painted on them once, but it could no longer have been read, on the most of them, now, even if there had been light.
A faint wind moaned through the trees, and Tom feared it might be the spirits of the dead, complaining at being disturbed. The boys talked little, and only under their breath, for the time and the place and the pervading solemnity and silence oppressed their spirits. They found the sharp new heap they were seeking, and ensconced themselves within the protection of three great elms that grew in a bunch within a few feet of the grave.

“I wish I’d said Mister Williams. But I never meant any harm. Everybody calls him Hoss.”

“Sh! There ’tis again! Didn’t you hear it?”
“I—”

“I’ll try to, Tom, but, Lord, I’m all of a shiver.”

The boys bent their heads together and scarcely breathed. A muffled sound of voices floated up from the far end of the graveyard.

“It’s devil-fire. Oh, Tom, this is awful.”

Potter and Injun Joe were carrying a handbarrow with a rope and a couple of shovels on it. They cast down their load and began to open the grave. The doctor put the lantern at the head of the grave and came and sat down with his back against one of the elm trees. He was so close the boys could have touched him.
“Hurry, men!” he said, in a low voice; “the moon might come out at any moment.”
They growled a response and went on digging. For some time there was no noise but the grating sound of the spades discharging their freight of mould and gravel. It was very monotonous. Finally a spade struck upon the coffin with a dull woody accent, and within another minute or two the men had hoisted it out on the ground. They pried off the lid with their shovels, got out the body and dumped it rudely on the ground. The moon drifted from behind the clouds and exposed the pallid face. The barrow was got ready and the corpse placed on it, covered with a blanket, and bound to its place with the rope. Potter took out a large spring-knife and cut off the dangling end of the rope and then said:
“Now the cussed thing’s ready, Sawbones, and you’ll just out with another five, or here she stays.”
“That’s the talk!” said Injun Joe.
“Look here, what does this mean?” said the doctor. “You required your pay in advance, and I’ve paid you.”
“Yes, and you done more than that,” said Injun Joe, approaching the doctor, who was now standing. “Five years ago you drove me away from your father’s kitchen one night, when I come to ask for something to eat, and you said I warn’t there for any good; and when I swore I’d get even with you if it took a hundred years, your father had me jailed for a vagrant. Did you think I’d forget? The Injun blood ain’t in me for nothing. And now I’ve got you, and you got to settle, you know!”
He was threatening the doctor, with his fist in his face, by this time.

events.text_segment:
“Lord, how is this, Joe?” he said.
“It’s a dirty business,” said Joe, without moving.
“What did you do it for?”
“I! I never done it!”
“Look here! That kind of talk won’t wash.”
Potter trembled and grew white.
“I thought I’d got sober. I’d no business to drink to-night. But it’s in my head yet—worse’n when we started here. I’m all in a muddle; can’t recollect anything of it, hardly. Tell me, Joe—honest, now, old feller—did I do it? Joe, I never meant to—’pon my soul and honor, I never meant to, Joe. Tell me how it was, Joe. Oh, it’s awful—and him so young and promising.”
“Why, you two was scuffling, and he fetched you one with the headboard and you fell flat; and then up you come, all reeling and staggering like, and snatched the knife and jammed it into him, just as he fetched you another awful clip—and here you’ve laid, as dead as a wedge til now.”
“Oh, I didn’t know what I was a-doing. I wish I may die this minute if I did. It was all on account of the whiskey and the excitement, I reckon. I never used a weepon in my life before, Joe. I’ve fought, but never with weepons. They’ll all say that. Joe, don’t tell! Say you won’t tell, Joe—that’s a good feller. I always liked you, Joe, and stood up for you, too. Don’t you remember? You won’t tell, will you, Joe?” And the poor creature dropped on his knees before the stolid murderer, and clasped his appealing hands.
“No, you’ve always been fair and square with me, Muff Potter, and I won’t go back on you. There, now, that’s as fair as a man can say.”
“Oh, Joe, you’re an angel. I’ll bless you for this the longest day I live.” And Potter began to cry.
“Come, now, that’s enough of that. This ain’t any time for blubbering. You be off yonder way and I’ll go this. Move, now, and don’t leave any tracks behind you.”
Potter started on a trot that quickly increased to a run. The half-breed stood looking after him. He muttered:
“If he’s as much stunned with the lick and fuddled with the rum as he had the look of being, he won’t think of the knife till he’s gone so far he’ll be afraid to come back after it to such a place by himself—chicken-heart!”
Two or three minutes later the murdered man, the blanketed corpse, the lidless coffin, and the open grave were under no inspection but the moon’s. The stillness was complete again, too.

events.text_segment:
The two boys flew on and on, toward the village, speechless with horror. They glanced backward over their shoulders from time to time, apprehensively, as if they feared they might be followed. Every stump that started up in their path seemed a man and an enemy, and made them catch their breath; and as they sped by some outlying cottages that lay near the village, the barking of the aroused watch-dogs seemed to give wings to their feet.
“If we can only get to the old tannery before we break down!” whispered Tom, in short catches between breaths. “I can’t stand it much longer.”
Huckleberry’s hard pantings were his only reply, and the boys fixed their eyes on the goal of their hopes and bent to their work to win it. They gained steadily on it, and at last, breast to breast, they burst through the open door and fell grateful and exhausted in the sheltering shadows beyond. By and by their pulses slowed down, and Tom whispered:
“Huckleberry, what do you reckon’ll come of this?”
“If Doctor Robinson dies, I reckon hanging’ll come of it.”
“Do you though?”
“Why, I know it, Tom.”
Tom thought a while, then he said:
“Who’ll tell? We?”
“What are you talking about? S’pose something happened and Injun Joe didn’t hang? Why, he’d kill us some time or other, just as dead sure as we’re a laying here.”
“That’s just what I was thinking to myself, Huck.”

events.title: Deciding on Silence and the Need for a Solemn Oath
detailed_summary: Huckleberry suggests that if anyone is to speak, it should be Muff Potter, provided he is foolish enough, as he is usually intoxicated.
Tom reflects and then points out a critical flaw: Muff Potter doesn't actually know what happened.
He explains that Potter was struck and incapacitated just as Injun Joe committed the act.
Tom questions whether Potter could have seen or comprehended anything in that state.
Huckleberry exclaims in agreement with Tom's realization.
Tom further speculates that the blow itself might have been fatal for Potter.

Huckleberry doubts this, reasoning that Potter's usual state of intoxication would make him resilient to such a blow, much like his own father when drunk. He concedes a sober man might have succumbed.
After another pause for thought, Tom directly asks Huckleberry if he is certain he can maintain silence.
Huckleberry stresses the absolute necessity of their silence, emphasizing that Injun Joe would not hesitate to kill them, like "drownding a couple of cats," if they spoke and he wasn't hanged.
He then proposes they formalize their commitment by swearing an oath to each other to remain "mum."
Tom readily agrees, seeing it as the best course of action.

When Tom suggests a simple hand-holding swear, Huckleberry rejects it as insufficient for such a grave matter, asserting that a serious oath like this requires writing and blood, unlike trivial promises, especially those made with girls who are prone to blabbing.

Tom said nothing—went on thinking. Presently he whispered:
“Huck, Muff Potter don’t know it. How can he tell?”
“What’s the reason he don’t know it?”
“Because he’d just got that whack when Injun Joe done it. D’you reckon he could see anything? D’you reckon he knowed anything?”
“By hokey, that’s so, Tom!”
“And besides, look-a-here—maybe that whack done for him!”
“No, ’taint likely, Tom. He had liquor in him; I could see that; and besides, he always has. Well, when pap’s full, you might take and belt him over the head with a church and you couldn’t phase him. He says so, his own self. So it’s the same with Muff Potter, of course. But if a man was dead sober, I reckon maybe that whack might fetch him; I dono.”

“Hucky, you sure you can keep mum?”
“Tom, we got to keep mum. You know that. That Injun devil wouldn’t make any more of drownding us than a couple of cats, if we was to squeak ’bout this and they didn’t hang him. Now, look-a-here, Tom, less take and swear to one another—that’s what we got to do—swear to keep mum.”
“I’m agreed. It’s the best thing. Would you just hold hands and swear that we—”
“Oh no, that wouldn’t do for this. That’s good enough for little rubbishy common things—specially with gals, cuz they go back on you anyway, and blab if they get in a huff—but there orter be writing ’bout a big thing like this. And blood.”

events.title: The Blood Oath Ceremony
detailed_summary: Tom is deeply impressed and excited by Huckleberry's solemn suggestion for a blood oath.
The gravity of the idea resonates with the dark hour, their terrifying experience, and the eerie surroundings of the tannery.
He finds a suitable writing surface, a clean pine shingle, illuminated by moonlight.
Using a piece of "red keel" (a type of red chalk or ochre) from his pocket, Tom meticulously scrawls their oath.
He emphasizes each downward stroke of the letters by biting his tongue, a sign of his intense concentration.
The oath declares that "Huck Finn and Tom Sawyer swears they will keep mum about This and They wish They may Drop down dead in Their Tracks if They ever Tell and Rot."
Huckleberry is full of admiration for Tom's literacy and the impressive, formal language of the oath.
Eager to complete the ritual, Huckleberry takes a pin from his lapel to draw blood.
Tom quickly stops him, warning that a brass pin might have "verdigrease" (verdigris, a poisonous green coating) on it.
He explains that verdigris is poison, implying it would be dangerous if ingested or introduced into a wound.
Tom then produces one of his needles, unwraps the thread, and each boy pricks his thumb to draw a drop of blood.
After some effort, Tom manages to sign his initials using his bloodied little finger as a makeshift pen.
He then instructs Huckleberry on how to form the letters H and F for his own signature.
With the oath signed in blood, they bury the shingle near the wall, accompanying the act with "dismal ceremonies and incantations," symbolically locking away their secret.
Unbeknownst to them, another person stealthily moves through a different part of the ruined building.

detailed_summary: Tom, trying to find a sliver of hope, chokes back his sobs and whispers for Huckleberry to look, pointing out that the stray dog has its back turned to them.

Tom agrees, and asks Huckleberry where the snoring is coming from.

A sense of adventure rekindles in the boys.
Tom cautiously asks Huckleberry if he dares to investigate if Tom leads the way.
Huckleberry expresses reluctance, voicing the fear that the snoring person might be Injun Joe.
Tom feels a momentary chill of fear but is soon overcome by curiosity. They agree to proceed stealthily, with the plan to flee if the snoring stops.
Tiptoeing one behind the other, they approach the source of the snoring.

The sleeping man moans and shifts, his face becoming visible in the moonlight: it is Muff Potter.
The boys, who had been frozen with fear when the man moved, are now relieved it isn't Injun Joe.
