As the earliest suspicion of dawn appeared on Sunday morning, Huck came groping up the hill and rapped gently at the old Welshman’s door. The old man, who had been awake for some time, opened it at once. Huck’s face was pale, his clothes were damp with dew, and his eyes were wide with exhaustion and fear.  

“Come in, boy,” the Welshman said in a low voice, stepping aside. “You look like you’ve seen a ghost.”  

Huck stumbled inside, his breath coming in short gasps. “I—I heard ’em,” he whispered. “Injun Joe and his partner. They was talkin’ ’bout the treasure—and revenge!”  

The Welshman’s brows furrowed. “Sit down, lad. Tell me everything.”  

Huck collapsed onto a wooden stool, his hands trembling. “I followed ’em last night, like I said I would. They went to the widow’s place—they was gonna hurt her, sir! But then they heard somebody comin’ and ran off. I—I didn’t know what to do, so I hid till mornin’.”  

The old man’s face darkened. “You did right to come straight here. We’ll see the widow’s protected.” He poured Huck a cup of strong coffee, which the boy clutched with both hands, the warmth steadying him.  

“There’s more,” Huck continued, his voice barely above a whisper. “They talked about a box—full of gold—hidden in the old haunted house by the river. They’re plannin’ to move it tonight.”  

The Welshman’s eyes gleamed. “Then we’ll be ready for ’em. But first, you need rest. You’re dead on your feet.”  

Huck shook his head. “I can’t—what if they go after the widow again?”  

“I’ll send word to the sheriff and have men posted near her house. You’ve done your part, son. Now let the grown-ups handle the rest.”  

Reluctantly, Huck allowed himself to be led to a cot in the corner. As soon as his head touched the pillow, exhaustion overtook him, and he fell into a deep sleep.  

Meanwhile, the Welshman hurried into town, spreading the news. By sunrise, the whole village was abuzz with whispers of Injun Joe’s return and the hidden treasure. Tom Sawyer, hearing the commotion, rushed to the Welshman’s house, where he found Huck still sleeping.  

“Is it true?” Tom demanded, shaking Huck awake. “Did you really hear ’em talk about the treasure?”  

Huck groaned, rubbing his eyes. “Yeah, but it ain’t safe, Tom. They’re dangerous!”  

Tom’s eyes sparkled with excitement. “We gotta get that gold before they do! Think of it, Huck—riches beyond our wildest dreams!”  

Huck sat up, his fear warring with temptation. “But what about Injun Joe? He’ll kill us if he catches us.”  

Tom grinned. “Not if we outsmart him. We’ll go tonight—just you and me. We’ll sneak in, take the treasure, and be gone before he even knows it!”  

Huck hesitated, but the lure of adventure—and wealth—was too strong. “All right,” he said at last. “But if we hear so much as a twig snap, we run.”  

Tom clapped him on the back. “Deal! Now, let’s make a plan.”  

As the two boys huddled together, plotting their daring raid, neither noticed the shadow that passed by the window—a shadow that moved with silent, deadly purpose.  

The hunt for the treasure had begun, but so had the danger. And in the quiet of that Sunday morning, fate was weaving a net around them all.

The Welshman’s sons departed at once. As they were leaving the room Huck sprang up and exclaimed:
“Oh, please don’t tell anybody it was me that blowed on them! Oh, please!”
“All right if you say it, Huck, but you ought to have the credit of what you did.”
“Oh no, no! Please don’t tell!”
When the young men were gone, the old Welshman said:
“They won’t tell—and I won’t. But why don’t you want it known?”
Huck would not explain, further than to say that he already knew too much about one of those men and would not have the man know that he knew anything against him for the whole world—he would be killed for knowing it, sure.
The old man promised secrecy once more, and said:
“How did you come to follow these fellows, lad? Were they looking suspicious?”
Huck was silent while he framed a duly cautious reply. Then he said:
“Well, you see, I’m a kind of a hard lot,—least everybody says so, and I don’t see nothing agin it—and sometimes I can’t sleep much, on account of thinking about it and sort of trying to strike out a new way of doing. That was the way of it last night. I couldn’t sleep, and so I come along upstreet ’bout midnight, a-turning it all over, and when I got to that old shackly brick store by the Temperance Tavern, I backed up agin the wall to have another think. Well, just then along comes these two chaps slipping along close by me, with something under their arm, and I reckoned they’d stole it. One was a-smoking, and t’other one wanted a light; so they stopped right before me and the cigars lit up their faces and I see that the big one was the deaf and dumb Spaniard, by his white whiskers and the patch on his eye, and t’other one was a rusty, ragged-looking devil.”
“Could you see the rags by the light of the cigars?”
This staggered Huck for a moment. Then he said:
“Well, I don’t know—but somehow it seems as if I did.”
“Then they went on, and you—”
“Follered ’em—yes. That was it. I wanted to see what was up—they sneaked along so. I dogged ’em to the widder’s stile, and stood in the dark and heard the ragged one beg for the widder, and the Spaniard swear he’d spile her looks just as I told you and your two—”
“What! The deaf and dumb man said all that!”
Huck had made another terrible mistake! He was trying his best to keep the old man from getting the faintest hint of who the Spaniard might be, and yet his tongue seemed determined to get him into trouble in spite of all he could do. He made several efforts to creep out of his scrape, but the old man’s eye was upon him and he made blunder after blunder. Presently the Welshman said:
“My boy, don’t be afraid of me. I wouldn’t hurt a hair of your head for all the world. No—I’d protect you—I’d protect you. This Spaniard is not deaf and dumb; you’ve let that slip without intending it; you can’t cover that up now. You know something about that Spaniard that you want to keep dark. Now trust me—tell me what it is, and trust me—I won’t betray you.”
Huck looked into the old man’s honest eyes a moment, then bent over and whispered in his ear:
“’Tain’t a Spaniard—it’s Injun Joe!”
The Welshman almost jumped out of his chair. In a moment he said:
“It’s all plain enough, now. When you talked about notching ears and slitting noses I judged that that was your own embellishment, because white men don’t take that sort of revenge. But an Injun! That’s a different matter altogether.”

The Welshman’s sons departed at once, their hearts pounding with excitement and determination. They had heard the old man’s tale of Injun Joe’s hidden treasure, and though they were skeptical at first, the urgency in their father’s voice convinced them that this was no mere wild goose chase. The night was dark, the air thick with the scent of damp earth and pine, as they made their way toward the abandoned house near the river—the very place where Tom and Huck had witnessed the murder weeks before.  

The eldest, a tall and broad-shouldered lad named Evan, carried a lantern, its flickering light casting eerie shadows on the gnarled trees lining the path. His younger brother, Rhys, clutched a shovel, his fingers tightening around the handle with every rustle in the underbrush.  

"Do you really think the treasure’s still there?" Rhys whispered, his voice barely audible over the chirping of crickets.  

Evan glanced back at him, his expression grim. "If it is, we’d best get to it before anyone else does. That devil Injun Joe may be dead, but there’s no telling who else might’ve caught wind of it."  

The brothers quickened their pace, their boots crunching on dry leaves as they approached the dilapidated house. The moon peeked through the clouds, illuminating the broken windows and sagging porch like ghostly eyes watching their every move.  

Inside, the air was musty, thick with the scent of rotting wood and mildew. Evan raised the lantern, its golden glow revealing the same room where Tom and Huck had hidden that fateful night. The floorboards creaked beneath their weight as they moved cautiously, scanning for any sign of the treasure.  

"Where do we even start?" Rhys muttered, kicking aside a pile of debris.  

Evan’s eyes fell upon the hearth—the very spot where Injun Joe had stood when he buried the loot. "There," he said, pointing. "Dig there."  

Rhys wasted no time. He drove the shovel into the dirt, the sharp *thunk* of metal striking earth echoing through the empty house. Evan knelt beside him, using his hands to scoop away loose soil. Minutes passed in tense silence, broken only by their labored breathing.  

Then—*clink*.  

Rhys froze. "Did you hear that?"  

Evan’s pulse quickened. He reached into the hole, his fingers brushing against something cold and metallic. With a sharp tug, he pulled free a small, rusted box. The brothers exchanged a glance, their eyes wide with disbelief.  

"It’s real," Rhys breathed.  

Evan pried open the lid, revealing a heap of gold coins and tarnished jewelry glinting in the lantern light. A fortune—enough to change their lives forever.  

But before they could celebrate, a floorboard groaned behind them.  

The brothers whirled around, their blood turning to ice.  

A shadowy figure stood in the doorway, silhouetted against the moonlight.  

"Looks like I ain’t the only one who knows about this little stash," a rough voice drawled.  

Evan’s grip tightened on the box. They weren’t alone—and their night was far from over.

During breakfast the talk went on, and in the course of it the old man said that the last thing which he and his sons had done, before going to bed, was to get a lantern and examine the stile and its vicinity for marks of blood. They found none, but captured a bulky bundle of—
“Of what?”
If the words had been lightning they could not have leaped with a more stunning suddenness from Huck’s blanched lips. His eyes were staring wide, now, and his breath suspended—waiting for the answer. The Welshman started—stared in return—three seconds—five seconds—ten—then replied:
“Of burglar’s tools. Why, what’s the matter with you?”
Huck sank back, panting gently, but deeply, unutterably grateful. The Welshman eyed him gravely, curiously—and presently said:
“Yes, burglar’s tools. That appears to relieve you a good deal. But what did give you that turn? What were you expecting we’d found?”
Huck was in a close place—the inquiring eye was upon him—he would have given anything for material for a plausible answer—nothing suggested itself—the inquiring eye was boring deeper and deeper—a senseless reply offered—there was no time to weigh it, so at a venture he uttered it—feebly:
“Sunday-school books, maybe.”
Poor Huck was too distressed to smile, but the old man laughed loud and joyously, shook up the details of his anatomy from head to foot, and ended by saying that such a laugh was money in a-man’s pocket, because it cut down the doctor’s bill like everything. Then he added:
“Poor old chap, you’re white and jaded—you ain’t well a bit—no wonder you’re a little flighty and off your balance. But you’ll come out of it. Rest and sleep will fetch you out all right, I hope.”
Huck was irritated to think he had been such a goose and betrayed such a suspicious excitement, for he had dropped the idea that the parcel brought from the tavern was the treasure, as soon as he had heard the talk at the widow’s stile. He had only thought it was not the treasure, however—he had not known that it wasn’t—and so the suggestion of a captured bundle was too much for his self-possession. But on the whole he felt glad the little episode had happened, for now he knew beyond all question that that bundle was not the bundle, and so his mind was at rest and exceedingly comfortable. In fact, everything seemed to be drifting just in the right direction, now; the treasure must be still in No. 2, the men would be captured and jailed that day, and he and Tom could seize the gold that night without any trouble or any fear of interruption.

events.title: Community Gathers, News Spreads, and a New Alarm for Tom and Becky
detailed_summary: A knock at the door startles Huck, who hides to avoid any connection with the recent events.
The Welshman admits several visitors, including the Widow Douglas, as townspeople gather near the stile, indicating the news has spread.
The Welshman recounts the night's events to the visitors, and the Widow Douglas expresses her gratitude for her rescue.
He hints at an unnamed hero responsible for their timely arrival, piquing immense curiosity but refusing to reveal Huck's identity.
The Widow Douglas wonders why she wasn't awakened during the commotion.
The Welshman explains they didn't want to frighten her, especially since the culprits were unlikely to return without their tools, and her servants guarded the house.
Later, at church, the attempted burglary is the main topic of conversation, with no sign of the villains found.
A new concern arises when Mrs. Thatcher asks Mrs. Harper about Becky, realizing Becky didn't stay with her.
Aunt Polly arrives, looking for Tom, assuming he stayed with either Mrs. Thatcher or Mrs. Harper and is now avoiding church.
Both Mrs. Thatcher and Mrs. Harper deny Tom stayed with them, leading to growing anxiety for Aunt Polly.
Joe Harper cannot confirm when he last saw Tom.
Whispers spread through the church as people realize Tom and Becky are missing, and no one recalls seeing them on the ferry; a young man voices the fear that they are still in the cave.
Mrs. Thatcher faints, and Aunt Polly becomes distraught.

Just as breakfast was completed there was a knock at the door. Huck jumped for a hiding-place, for he had no mind to be connected even remotely with the late event. The Welshman admitted several ladies and gentlemen, among them the Widow Douglas, and noticed that groups of citizens were climbing up the hill—to stare at the stile. So the news had spread. The Welshman had to tell the story of the night to the visitors. The widow’s gratitude for her preservation was outspoken.
“Don’t say a word about it, madam. There’s another that you’re more beholden to than you are to me and my boys, maybe, but he don’t allow me to tell his name. We wouldn’t have been there but for him.”
Of course this excited a curiosity so vast that it almost belittled the main matter—but the Welshman allowed it to eat into the vitals of his visitors, and through them be transmitted to the whole town, for he refused to part with his secret. When all else had been learned, the widow said:
“I went to sleep reading in bed and slept straight through all that noise. Why didn’t you come and wake me?”
“We judged it warn’t worth while. Those fellows warn’t likely to come again—they hadn’t any tools left to work with, and what was the use of waking you up and scaring you to death? My three negro men stood guard at your house all the rest of the night. They’ve just come back.”
More visitors came, and the story had to be told and retold for a couple of hours more.
There was no Sabbath-school during day-school vacation, but everybody was early at church. The stirring event was well canvassed. News came that not a sign of the two villains had been yet discovered. When the sermon was finished, Judge Thatcher’s wife dropped alongside of Mrs. Harper as she moved down the aisle with the crowd and said:
“Is my Becky going to sleep all day? I just expected she would be tired to death.”
“Your Becky?”
“Yes,” with a startled look—“didn’t she stay with you last night?”
“Why, no.”
Mrs. Thatcher turned pale, and sank into a pew, just as Aunt Polly, talking briskly with a friend, passed by. Aunt Polly said:
“Goodmorning, Mrs. Thatcher. Goodmorning, Mrs. Harper. I’ve got a boy that’s turned up missing. I reckon my Tom stayed at your house last night—one of you. And now he’s afraid to come to church. I’ve got to settle with him.”
Mrs. Thatcher shook her head feebly and turned paler than ever.
“He didn’t stay with us,” said Mrs. Harper, beginning to look uneasy. A marked anxiety came into Aunt Polly’s face.
“Joe Harper, have you seen my Tom this morning?”
“No’m.”
“When did you see him last?”
Joe tried to remember, but was not sure he could say. The people had stopped moving out of church. Whispers passed along, and a boding uneasiness took possession of every countenance. Children were anxiously questioned, and young teachers. They all said they had not noticed whether Tom and Becky were on board the ferryboat on the homeward trip; it was dark; no one thought of inquiring if any one was missing. One young man finally blurted out his fear that they were still in the cave! Mrs. Thatcher swooned away. Aunt Polly fell to crying and wringing her hands.

Just as breakfast was completed there was a knock at the door. Tom, still groggy from his late-night adventures, nearly jumped out of his skin. Aunt Polly, wiping her hands on her apron, shot him a suspicious glance before shuffling toward the entrance.  

"Who could that be at this hour?" she muttered, lifting the latch.

Tom’s shoulders slumped. "But Aunt Polly, it’s awful hot already. The paint’ll dry too fast if I do it now."  

Huck, sensing an opportunity, chimed in. "I could help him, ma’am. We’d get it done twice as quick."  

Aunt Polly hesitated, her stern expression softening just a fraction. She knew Tom’s tricks all too well, but the idea of the fence being finished sooner was tempting. "Very well," she said at last. "But if that fence isn’t gleaming white by noon, there’ll be no fishing for a week!"

events.title: Town's Frantic Search for Missing Children and Huck's Illness
detailed_summary: The news of Tom and Becky's disappearance spreads rapidly, causing widespread panic and overshadowing the recent burglary attempt.
The town quickly mobilizes a large search party, with men on horses and boats heading towards the cave.
The village feels deserted as the search continues through the afternoon.
Many women visit and console Aunt Polly and Mrs. Thatcher.
The town anxiously awaits news throughout the night, but the only message by morning is a request for more candles and food for the searchers.
Judge Thatcher sends encouraging messages from the cave, but they offer little comfort.
The Welshman returns near daylight, exhausted and covered in candle-grease and clay, to find Huck delirious with fever.
With physicians at the cave, the Widow Douglas takes on the responsibility of caring for Huck, believing it her duty.
The Welshman affirms Huck's good qualities, which the Widow attributes to a divine mark.
Search parties begin to return to the village, weary, while the most resilient continue exploring uncharted parts of the cavern.
The names 'BECKY & TOM' are discovered traced with candle-smoke on a cave wall, along with a soiled ribbon belonging to Becky.
Mrs. Thatcher, recognizing the ribbon, mourns it as the last relic of her child.
Hopeful shouts from searchers in the cave occasionally arise but always end in disappointment as they realize it's just another searcher's light, not the children.

events.text_segment:
The alarm swept from lip to lip, from group to group, from street to street, and within five minutes the bells were wildly clanging and the whole town was up! The Cardiff Hill episode sank into instant insignificance, the burglars were forgotten, horses were saddled, skiffs were manned, the ferryboat ordered out, and before the horror was half an hour old, two hundred men were pouring down highroad and river toward the cave.
All the long afternoon the village seemed empty and dead. Many women visited Aunt Polly and Mrs. Thatcher and tried to comfort them. They cried with them, too, and that was still better than words. All the tedious night the town waited for news; but when the morning dawned at last, all the word that came was, “Send more candles—and send food.” Mrs. Thatcher was almost crazed; and Aunt Polly, also. Judge Thatcher sent messages of hope and encouragement from the cave, but they conveyed no real cheer.
The old Welshman came home toward daylight, spattered with candle-grease, smeared with clay, and almost worn out. He found Huck still in the bed that had been provided for him, and delirious with fever. The physicians were all at the cave, so the Widow Douglas came and took charge of the patient. She said she would do her best by him, because, whether he was good, bad, or indifferent, he was the Lord’s, and nothing that was the Lord’s was a thing to be neglected. The Welshman said Huck had good spots in him, and the widow said:
“You can depend on it. That’s the Lord’s mark. He don’t leave it off. He never does. Puts it somewhere on every creature that comes from his hands.”
Early in the forenoon parties of jaded men began to straggle into the village, but the strongest of the citizens continued searching. All the news that could be gained was that remotenesses of the cavern were being ransacked that had never been visited before; that every corner and crevice was going to be thoroughly searched; that wherever one wandered through the maze of passages, lights were to be seen flitting hither and thither in the distance, and shoutings and pistol-shots sent their hollow reverberations to the ear down the sombre aisles. In one place, far from the section usually traversed by tourists, the names “BECKY & TOM” had been found traced upon the rocky wall with candle-smoke, and near at hand a grease-soiled bit of ribbon. Mrs. Thatcher recognized the ribbon and cried over it. She said it was the last relic she should ever have of her child; and that no other memorial of her could ever be so precious, because this one parted latest from the living body before the awful death came. Some said that now and then, in the cave, a far-away speck of light would glimmer, and then a glorious shout would burst forth and a score of men go trooping down the echoing aisle—and then a sickening disappointment always followed; the children were not there; it was only a searcher’s light.

The sleepy village of St. Petersburg, usually so quiet in the early hours, was now alive with frantic energy. Lanterns flickered in windows, doors slammed, and voices rose in a chorus of confusion and fear.  

"Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn are missing!" cried one woman, clutching her shawl tightly around her shoulders.  

"Lost in the cave!" shouted another, her face pale with dread.  

The news spread like wildfire, igniting panic in every heart. Mothers hugged their children close, fathers grabbed lanterns and ropes, and even the old men who usually sat whittling on their porches now hurried to join the search. The thought of those two boys trapped in the dark, winding passages of McDougal’s Cave was too terrible to bear.  

Judge Thatcher, his face grim, organized the men into search parties. "We must move quickly," he declared. "Every minute counts!"  

Aunt Polly, her hands trembling, could barely speak through her tears. "Oh, if only I hadn’t scolded him so harshly yesterday," she whispered to Mrs. Harper. "What if—what if we never find him?"  

Mrs. Harper, equally distraught, could only shake her head, her own heart heavy with worry for Joe.  

The townspeople surged toward the cave, their lanterns casting long, flickering shadows on the road. The night air was thick with tension, and even the stars seemed to dim in sympathy.  

Meanwhile, deep within the cave, Tom and Huck sat huddled together, their own small candle barely holding back the oppressive darkness. They had wandered too far, lured by curiosity, and now they were hopelessly lost. The walls seemed to close in around them, and the eerie silence was broken only by the distant drip of water.  

"Do you think they’ll find us, Tom?" Huck asked, his voice small and shaky.  

Tom, though just as scared, forced a brave face. "’Course they will, Huck. Ain’t no cave can hold Tom Sawyer for long!"  

But as the hours dragged on, even Tom’s optimism began to waver. The candle burned lower, and the shadows grew longer.  

Back in town, the search parties scoured every inch of the cave’s entrance, calling the boys’ names until their voices grew hoarse. The night wore on, and hope began to fade.  

Then, just as the first light of dawn touched the horizon, a faint cry echoed from deep within the cave. The searchers froze, listening intently.  

"Did you hear that?" someone shouted.  

"It’s them! It’s them!"  

With renewed energy, the men plunged into the darkness, following the sound of the boys’ voices. And at last, after what felt like an eternity, Tom and Huck were pulled from the jaws of the cave, blinking in the morning light, exhausted but alive.  

The town erupted in cheers and tears of relief. Aunt Polly hugged Tom so tightly he thought he might burst, while Huck, unused to such attention, stood awkwardly but gratefully among the crowd.  

The adventure had been thrilling, but as Tom later admitted to Huck, "I reckon next time, we’d best stick to piratin’ on the river. Caves ain’t half as forgivin’ as the Mississippi!"  

And with that, the two friends limped home, wiser—and far more cautious—than before.

events.title: Huck's Fevered Inquiry and a Painful Misunderstanding
detailed_summary: After three agonizing days and nights, the village is in a state of despair.
Even the significant news of liquor being found at the Temperance Tavern barely registers with the public.
Huck, in a moment of lucidity during his illness, cautiously asks the Widow Douglas if anything was discovered at the Temperance Tavern.
The Widow confirms that liquor was found and the tavern has been closed.
Huck, becoming agitated, presses further, specifically asking if Tom Sawyer was the one who found 'it' (meaning the treasure).
The Widow Douglas, misinterpreting Huck's question and overwhelmed by her grief for the missing Tom, bursts into tears, urging Huck to be quiet due to his sickness.
Huck concludes that only liquor was found, as gold would have caused a bigger commotion, and believes the treasure is lost forever.
He is puzzled by the Widow's tears but, exhausted by his thoughts and illness, falls asleep.
The Widow reflects on Huck's question about Tom finding 'it', lamenting that few still have the hope or strength to continue searching for Tom Sawyer.

events.text_segment:
Three dreadful days and nights dragged their tedious hours along, and the village sank into a hopeless stupor. No one had heart for anything. The accidental discovery, just made, that the proprietor of the Temperance Tavern kept liquor on his premises, scarcely fluttered the public pulse, tremendous as the fact was. In a lucid interval, Huck feebly led up to the subject of taverns, and finally asked—dimly dreading the worst—if anything had been discovered at the Temperance Tavern since he had been ill.
“Yes,” said the widow.
Huck started up in bed, wildeyed:
“What? What was it?”
“Liquor!—and the place has been shut up. Lie down, child—what a turn you did give me!”
“Only tell me just one thing—only just one—please! Was it Tom Sawyer that found it?”
The widow burst into tears. “Hush, hush, child, hush! I’ve told you before, you must not talk. You are very, very sick!”
Then nothing but liquor had been found; there would have been a great powwow if it had been the gold. So the treasure was gone forever—gone forever! But what could she be crying about? Curious that she should cry.
These thoughts worked their dim way through Huck’s mind, and under the weariness they gave him he fell asleep. The widow said to herself:
“There—he’s asleep, poor wreck. Tom Sawyer find it! Pity but somebody could find Tom Sawyer! Ah, there ain’t many left, now, that’s got hope enough, or strength enough, either, to go on searching.”

events.title: Initial Cave Exploration and Discovery of a Hidden Passage
detailed_summary: Tom and Becky participated in the picnic activities, exploring the familiar, named sections of the cave with the larger group.
After engaging in hide-and-seek, they felt tired and decided to wander away from the others.
They amused themselves by examining the names, dates, and addresses written in candle smoke on the cave walls.
As they continued talking and drifting, they entered a part of the cave that lacked these smoke frescoes.
They inscribed their own names with candle smoke beneath an overhanging rock formation before moving on.
Their exploration led them to a striking natural feature: a limestone deposit shaped like a miniature Niagara Falls, formed over ages by trickling water.

Tom managed to get behind this formation to light it up for Becky and, in doing so, discovered it concealed a narrow, steep natural staircase, which immediately ignited his ambition to be an explorer.

events.text_segment: Now to return to Tom and Becky’s share in the picnic. They tripped along the murky aisles with the rest of the company, visiting the familiar wonders of the cave—wonders dubbed with rather over-descriptive names, such as “The Drawing-Room,” “The Cathedral,” “Aladdin’s Palace,” and so on. Presently the hide-and-seek frolicking began, and Tom and Becky engaged in it with zeal until the exertion began to grow a trifle wearisome; then they wandered down a sinuous avenue holding their candles aloft and reading the tangled webwork of names, dates, postoffice addresses, and mottoes with which the rocky walls had been frescoed (in candle-smoke). Still drifting along and talking, they scarcely noticed that they were now in a part of the cave whose walls were not frescoed. They smoked their own names under an overhanging shelf and moved on. Presently they came to a place where a little stream of water, trickling over a ledge and carrying a limestone sediment with it, had, in the slow-dragging ages, formed a laced and ruffled Niagara in gleaming and imperishable stone. Tom squeezed his small body behind it in order to illuminate it for Becky’s gratification. He found that it curtained a sort of steep natural stairway which was enclosed between narrow walls, and at once the ambition to be a discoverer seized him.

**text_segment**:  
Now to return to Tom and Becky’s share in the picnic. They wandered away from the rest of the party, and presently sat down to rest upon a mossy seat under a spreading live-oak. They had no thought of time, and when they did think of it, it was only to wonder how late it was getting. They were silent awhile, and then Tom said:  

“Becky, I—I wonder how long we’ve been down here?”  

“I don’t know.”  

“Reckon it’s most supper-time?”  

“I reckon so.”  

“I wish we had something to eat. I’m getting mighty hungry.”  

“So’m I.”  

Tom looked about him and said:  

“Becky, we’re lost!”  

She burst into tears.  

“Oh, Tom, we’re lost! we’re lost! We never can get out of this awful place! Oh, why did we ever leave the others!”  

She sank to the ground and cried so bitterly that Tom was appalled with the idea that she might die, or lose her reason. He sat down by her and put his arms around her; she buried her face in his bosom, she clung to him, she poured out her terrors, her unavailing regrets, and the far echoes turned them all to jeering laughter. Tom begged her to pluck up hope again, and she said she could not. He fell to blaming and abusing himself for getting her into this miserable situation; this had a better effect. She said she would try to hope again, she would get up and follow wherever he might lead if only he would not talk like that any more. For he was no more to blame than she, she said.  

So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving. For a little while, hope made a show of reviving—not with any reason to back it, but only because it is its nature to revive when the spring has not been taken out of it by age and familiarity with failure.  

By and by Tom took Becky’s candle and blew it out. This economy meant so much! Words were not needed. Becky understood, and her hope died again. She knew that Tom had a whole candle and three or four pieces in his pockets—yet he must economize.  

By and by fatigue began to assert its claims; the children tried to pay no attention, for it was dreadful to think of sitting down when time was grown to be so precious; moving, in some direction, in any direction, was at least progress and might bear fruit; but to sit down was to invite death and shorten its pursuit.  

At last Becky’s frail limbs refused to carry her farther. She sat down. Tom rested with her, and they talked of home, and the friends there, and the comfortable beds and, above all, the light! Becky cried, and Tom tried to think of some way of comforting her, but all his encouragements were grown threadbare with use, and sounded like sarcasms. Fatigue bore so heavily upon Becky that she drowsed off to sleep. Tom was grateful. He sat looking into her drawn face and saw it grow smooth and natural under the influence of pleasant dreams; and by and by a smile dawned there and stayed there. The peaceful face reflected somewhat of peace and healing into his own spirit, and his thoughts wandered away to bygone times and dreamy memories. While he was deep in his musings, Becky woke up with a breezy little laugh—but it was stricken dead upon her lips, and a groan followed it.  

“Oh, how could I sleep! I wish I never, never had waked! No! No, I don’t, Tom! Don’t look so! I won’t say it again.”  

“I’m glad you’ve slept, Becky; you’ll feel rested, now, and we’ll find the way out.”  

“We can try, Tom; but I’ve seen such a beautiful country in my dream. I reckon we are going there.”  

“Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”  

They rose up and wandered along, hand in hand and hopeless. They tried to estimate how long they had been in the cave, but all they knew was that it seemed days and weeks, and yet it was plain that this could not be, for their candles were not gone yet. A long time after this—they could not tell how long—Tom said they must go softly and listen for dripping water—they must find a spring. They found one presently, and Tom said it was time to rest again. Both were cruelly tired, yet Becky said she thought she could go a little farther. She was surprised to hear Tom dissent. She could not understand it. They sat down, and Tom fastened his candle to the wall in front of them with some clay. Thought was soon busy; nothing was said for some time. Then Becky broke the silence:  

“Tom, I am so hungry!”  

Tom took something out of his pocket.  

“Do you remember this?” he said.  

Becky almost smiled.  

“It’s our wedding-cake, Tom.”  

“Yes—I wish it was as big as a barrel, for it’s all we’ve got.”  

“I saved it from the picnic for us to dream on, Tom, the way grown-up people do with wedding-cake—but it’ll be our—”  

She stopped short. Tom divided the cake and Becky ate with good appetite, while Tom nibbled at his moiety. There was abundance of cold water to finish the feast with. By and by Becky suggested that they move on again. Tom was silent a moment. Then he said:  

“Becky, can you bear it if I tell you something?”  

Becky’s face paled, but she thought she could.  

“Well, then, Becky, we must stay here, where there’s water to drink. That little piece is our last candle!”  

Becky gave loose to tears and wailings. Tom did what he could to comfort her, but with little effect. At length Becky said:  

“Tom!”  

“Well, Becky?”  

“They’ll miss us and hunt for us!”  

“Yes, they will! Certainly they will!”  

“Maybe they’re hunting for us now, Tom.”  

“Why, I reckon maybe they are. I hope they are.”  

“When would they miss us, Tom?”  

“When they get back to the boat, I reckon.”  

“Tom, it might be dark then—would they notice we hadn’t come?”  

“I don’t know. But anyway, your mother would miss you as soon as they got home.”  

A frightened look in Becky’s face brought Tom to his senses and he saw that he had made a blunder. Becky was not to have gone home that night! The children became silent and thoughtful. A new pang of sorrow came upon Becky; Tom saw that she was thinking of what he was thinking of—that the Sabbath morning might be half spent before Mrs. Thatcher discovered that Becky was not at Mrs. Harper’s.  

The children fastened their eyes upon their bit of candle and watched it melt slowly and pitilessly away; saw the half inch of wick stand alone at last; saw the feeble flame rise and fall, climb the thin column of smoke, linger at its top a moment, and then—the horror of utter darkness reigned!  

How long afterward it was that Becky came to a slow consciousness that she was crying in Tom’s arms, neither could tell. All that they knew was, that after what seemed a mighty stretch of time, both awoke out of a dead stupor of sleep and resumed their miseries once more. Tom said it might be Sunday, now—maybe Monday. He tried to get Becky to talk, but her sorrows were too oppressive, all her hopes were gone. Tom said that they must have been missed long ago, and no doubt the search was going on. He would shout now, and maybe some one would come. He tried it; but in the darkness the distant echoes sounded so hideously that he tried it no more.  

The children ate their cake, and were better by and by. Then Tom proposed that they try to grope their way along the passage once more. He took Becky’s hand and they felt their way along in the dark with sinking hearts, utterly hopeless, not knowing whither they were going, merely creeping, creeping, creeping, till Becky’s strength was entirely gone, and she had to be carried. Tom took her in his arms and staggered on, making as little noise as he could, for he was afraid of attracting the attention of the bats; but he must go on, he said, if he dropped dead the next minute.  

At last his strength gave out, and he set Becky down. He stretched himself beside her, and they slept the sleep of the weary. When they awoke, they were famished and wretched. Tom believed it must be Tuesday by this time.  

Now an idea struck him. There were some side passages near at hand. It would be better to explore these than bear the weight of the heavy time in idleness. He took a kite-line from his pocket, tied it to a projection, and he and Becky started, Tom in the lead, unwinding the line as he groped along. At the end of twenty steps the corridor ended in a “jumping-off place.” Tom got down on his knees and felt below, and then as far around the corner as he could reach with his hands conveniently; he made an effort to stretch yet a little farther to the right, and at that moment, not twenty yards away, a human hand, holding a candle, appeared from behind a rock! Tom lifted up a glorious shout, and instantly that hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe’s! Tom was paralyzed; he could not move. He was vastly gratified the next moment to see the “Spaniard” take to his heels and get himself out of the way. Tom wondered that Joe had not recognized his voice and come over and murdered him for testifying in court. But the echoes must have disguised the voice. Without doubt, that was it, he reasoned. Tom’s fright weakened every muscle in his body. He said to himself that if he had strength enough to get back to the spring he would stay there, and nothing should tempt him to run the risk of meeting Injun Joe again. He was careful to keep from Becky what it was he had seen. He told her he had only shouted “for luck.”  

But hunger and wretchedness rise superior to fears in the long run. Another tedious wait at the spring and another long sleep brought changes. The children awoke tortured with a raging hunger. Tom believed that it must be Wednesday or Thursday or even Friday or Saturday, now, and that the search had been given over. He proposed to explore another passage. He felt willing to risk Injun Joe and all other terrors. But Becky was very weak. She had sunk into a dreary apathy and would not be roused. She said she would wait, now, where she was, and die—it would not be long. She told Tom to go with the kite-line and explore if he chose; but she implored him to come back every little while and speak to her; and she made him promise that when the awful time came, he would stay by her and hold her hand until all was over.  

Tom kissed her, with a choking sensation in his throat, and made a show of being confident of finding the searchers or an escape from the cave; then he took the kite-line in his hand and went groping down one of the passages on his hands and knees, distressed with hunger and sick with bodings of coming doom.  

This passage is from *The Adventures of Tom Sawyer* by Mark Twain, specifically from **Chapter XXXI**, where Tom and Becky become lost in the cave. The segment captures their fear, exhaustion, and fleeting hope as they struggle to find a way out.

While he was deep in his musings, Becky woke up with a breezy little laugh—but it was stricken dead upon her lips, and a groan followed it.  

“Oh, how could I sleep! I wish I never, never had waked! No! No, I don’t, Tom! Don’t look so! I won’t say it again.”  

“I’m glad you’ve slept, Becky; you’ll feel rested, now, and we’ll find the way out.”  

“We can try, Tom; but I’ve seen such a beautiful country in my dream. I reckon we are going there.”  

“Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”  

They rose up and wandered along, hand in hand and hopeless. They tried to estimate how long they had been in the cave, but all they knew was that it seemed days and weeks, and yet it was plain that this could not be, for their candles were not gone yet. A long time after this—they could not tell how long—Tom said they must go softly and listen for dripping water—they must find a spring. They found one presently, and Tom said it was time to rest again. Both were cruelly tired, yet Becky said she thought she could go a little farther. She was surprised to hear Tom dissent. She could not understand it. They sat down, and Tom fastened his candle to the wall in front of them with some clay. Thought was soon busy; nothing was said for some time. Then Becky broke the silence:  

“Tom, I am so hungry!”  

Tom took something out of his pocket.  

“Do you remember this?” he said.  

Becky almost smiled.  

“It’s our wedding-cake, Tom.”  

“Yes—I wish it was as big as a barrel, for it’s all we’ve got.”  

“I saved it from the picnic for us to dream on, Tom, the way grown-up people do with wedding-cake—but it’ll be our—”  

She stopped short. Tom divided the cake and Becky ate with good appetite, while Tom nibbled at his moiety. There was abundance of cold water to finish the feast with. By and by Becky suggested that they move on again. Tom was silent a moment. Then he said:  

“Becky, can you bear it if I tell you something?”  

Becky’s face paled, but she thought she could.  

“Well, then, Becky, we must stay here, where there’s water to drink. That little piece is our last candle!”  

Becky gave loose to tears and wailings. Tom did what he could to comfort her, but with little effect. At length Becky said:  

“Tom!”  

“Well, Becky?”  

“They’ll miss us and hunt for us!”  

“Yes, they will! Certainly they will!”  

“Maybe they’re hunting for us now, Tom.”  

“Why, I reckon maybe they are. I hope they are.”  

“When would they miss us, Tom?”  

“When they get back to the boat, I reckon.”  

“Tom, it might be dark then—would they notice we hadn’t come?”  

“I don’t know. But anyway, your mother would miss you as soon as they got home.”  

A frightened look in Becky’s face brought Tom to his senses and he saw that he had made a blunder. Becky was not to have gone home that night! The children became silent and thoughtful. A new pang of sorrow came upon Becky; Tom saw that she was thinking of what he was thinking of—that the Sabbath morning might be half spent before Mrs. Thatcher discovered that Becky was not at Mrs. Harper’s.  

The children fastened their eyes upon their bit of candle and watched it melt slowly and pitilessly away; saw the half inch of wick stand alone at last; saw the feeble flame rise and fall, climb the thin column of smoke, linger at its top a moment, and then—the horror of utter darkness reigned!  

How long afterward it was that Becky came to a slow consciousness that she was crying in Tom’s arms, neither could tell. All that they knew was, that after what seemed a mighty stretch of time, both awoke out of a dead stupor of sleep and resumed their miseries once more. Tom said it might be Sunday, now—maybe Monday. He tried to get Becky to talk, but her sorrows were too oppressive, all her hopes were gone. Tom said that they must have been missed long ago, and no doubt the search was going on. He would shout now, and maybe some one would come. He tried it; but in the darkness the distant echoes sounded so hideously that he tried it no more.  

The children ate their cake, and were better by and by. Then Tom proposed that they try to grope their way along the passage once more. He took Becky’s hand and they felt their way along in the dark with sinking hearts, utterly hopeless, not knowing whither they were going, merely creeping, creeping, creeping, till Becky’s strength was entirely gone, and she had to be carried. Tom took her in his arms and staggered on, making as little noise as he could, for he was afraid of attracting the attention of the bats; but he must go on, he said, if he dropped dead the next minute.  

At last his strength gave out, and he set Becky down. He stretched himself beside her, and they slept the sleep of the weary. When they awoke, they were famished and wretched. Tom believed it must be Tuesday by this time.  

Now an idea struck him. There were some side passages near at hand. It would be better to explore these than bear the weight of the heavy time in idleness. He took a kite-line from his pocket, tied it to a projection, and he and Becky started, Tom in the lead, unwinding the line as he groped along. At the end of twenty steps the corridor ended in a “jumping-off place.” Tom got down on his knees and felt below, and then as far around the corner as he could reach with his hands conveniently; he made an effort to stretch yet a little farther to the right, and at that moment, not twenty yards away, a human hand, holding a candle, appeared from behind a rock! Tom lifted up a glorious shout, and instantly that hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe’s! Tom was paralyzed; he could not move. He was vastly gratified the next moment to see the “Spaniard” take to his heels and get himself out of the way. Tom wondered that Joe had not recognized his voice and come over and murdered him for testifying in court. But the echoes must have disguised the voice. Without doubt, that was it, he reasoned. Tom’s fright weakened every muscle in his body. He said to himself that if he had strength enough to get back to the spring he would stay there, and nothing should tempt him to run the risk of meeting Injun Joe again. He was careful to keep from Becky what it was he had seen. He told her he had only shouted “for luck.”  

But hunger and wretchedness rise superior to fears in the long run. Another tedious wait at the spring and another long sleep brought changes. The children awoke tortured with a raging hunger. Tom believed that it must be Wednesday or Thursday or even Friday or Saturday, now, and that the search had been given over. He proposed to explore another passage. He felt willing to risk Injun Joe and all other terrors. But Becky was very weak. She had sunk into a dreary apathy and would not be roused. She said she would wait, now, where she was, and die—it would not be long. She told Tom to go with the kite-line and explore if he chose; but she implored him to come back every little while and speak to her; and she made him promise that when the awful time came, he would stay by her and hold her hand until all was over.  

Tom kissed her, with a choking sensation in his throat, and made a show of being confident of finding the searchers or an escape from the cave; then he took the kite-line in his hand and went groping down one of the passages on his hands and knees, distressed with hunger and sick with bodings of coming doom.  

This passage is from *The Adventures of Tom Sawyer* by Mark Twain, specifically from **Chapter XXXI**, where Tom and Becky become lost in the cave. The segment captures their fear, exhaustion, and fleeting hope as they struggle to find a way out.

Becky responded to his call, and they made a smoke-mark for future guidance, and started upon their quest. They wound this way and that, far down into the secret depths of the cave, made another mark, and branched off in search of novelties to tell the upper world about. In one place they found a spacious cavern, from whose ceiling depended a multitude of shining stalactites of the length and circumference of a man’s leg; they walked all about it, wondering and admiring, and presently left it by one of the numerous passages that opened into it. This shortly brought them to a bewitching spring, whose basin was incrusted with a frostwork of glittering crystals; it was in the midst of a cavern whose walls were supported by many fantastic pillars which had been formed by the joining of great stalactites and stalagmites together, the result of the ceaseless water-drip of centuries. Under the roof vast knots of bats had packed themselves together, thousands in a bunch; the lights disturbed the creatures and they came flocking down by hundreds, squeaking and darting furiously at the candles. Tom knew their ways and the danger of this sort of conduct. He seized Becky’s hand and hurried her into the first corridor that offered; and none too soon, for a bat struck Becky’s light out with its wing while she was passing out of the cavern. The bats chased the children a good distance; but the fugitives plunged into every new passage that offered, and at last got rid of the perilous things. Tom found a subterranean lake, shortly, which stretched its dim length away until its shape was lost in the shadows. He wanted to explore its borders, but concluded that it would be best to sit down and rest awhile, first. Now, for the first time, the deep stillness of the place laid a clammy hand upon the spirits of the children. Becky said:
“Why, I didn’t notice, but it seems ever so long since I heard any of the others.”
“Come to think, Becky, we are away down below them—and I don’t know how far away north, or south, or east, or whichever it is. We couldn’t hear them here.”
Becky grew apprehensive.
“I wonder how long we’ve been down here, Tom? We better start back.”
“Yes, I reckon we better. P’raps we better.”
“Can you find the way, Tom? It’s all a mixed-up crookedness to me.”
“I reckon I could find it—but then the bats. If they put our candles out it will be an awful fix. Let’s try some other way, so as not to go through there.”
“Well. But I hope we won’t get lost. It would be so awful!” and the girl shuddered at the thought of the dreadful possibilities.

events.text_segment:
They started through a corridor, and traversed it in silence a long way, glancing at each new opening, to see if there was anything familiar about the look of it; but they were all strange. Every time Tom made an examination, Becky would watch his face for an encouraging sign, and he would say cheerily:
“Oh, it’s all right. This ain’t the one, but we’ll come to it right away!”
But he felt less and less hopeful with each failure, and presently began to turn off into diverging avenues at sheer random, in desperate hope of finding the one that was wanted. He still said it was “all right,” but there was such a leaden dread at his heart that the words had lost their ring and sounded just as if he had said, “All is lost!” Becky clung to his side in an anguish of fear, and tried hard to keep back the tears, but they would come. At last she said:
“Oh, Tom, never mind the bats, let’s go back that way! We seem to get worse and worse off all the time.”
“Listen!” said he.
Profound silence; silence so deep that even their breathings were conspicuous in the hush. Tom shouted. The call went echoing down the empty aisles and died out in the distance in a faint sound that resembled a ripple of mocking laughter.
“Oh, don’t do it again, Tom, it is too horrid,” said Becky.
“It is horrid, but I better, Becky; they might hear us, you know,” and he shouted again.
The “might” was even a chillier horror than the ghostly laughter, it so confessed a perishing hope. The children stood still and listened; but there was no result. Tom turned upon the back track at once, and hurried his steps. It was but a little while before a certain indecision in his manner revealed another fearful fact to Becky—he could not find his way back!
“Oh, Tom, you didn’t make any marks!”
“Becky, I was such a fool! Such a fool! I never thought we might want to come back! No—I can’t find the way. It’s all mixed up.”
“Tom, Tom, we’re lost! we’re lost! We never can get out of this awful place! Oh, why did we ever leave the others!”
She sank to the ground and burst into such a frenzy of crying that Tom was appalled with the idea that she might die, or lose her reason. He sat down by her and put his arms around her; she buried her face in his bosom, she clung to him, she poured out her terrors, her unavailing regrets, and the far echoes turned them all to jeering laughter. Tom begged her to pluck up hope again, and she said she could not. He fell to blaming and abusing himself for getting her into this miserable situation; this had a better effect. She said she would try to hope again, she would get up and follow wherever he might lead if only he would not talk like that any more. For he was no more to blame than she, she said.

They started through a corridor, and traversed it in silence a long way, glancing at each new opening, to see if there was anything familiar about the look of it; but they were all strange. Every time Tom made an examination, Becky would watch his face for an encouraging sign, and he would say cheerily:  

"Oh, it's all right. This ain't the one, but we'll come to it right away!"  

But he felt less and less hopeful with each failure, and presently began to turn off into diverging avenues at sheer random, in desperate hope of finding the one that was wanted. He still said it was "all right," but there was such a leaden dread at his heart that the words had lost their ring and sounded just as if he had said, "All is lost!" Becky clung to his side in an anguish of fear, and tried hard to keep back the tears, but they would come. At last she said:  

"Oh, Tom, never mind the bats, let's go back that way! We seem to get worse and worse off all the time."  

Tom stopped.  

"Listen!" said he.  

Profound silence; silence so deep that even their breathings were conspicuous in the hush. Tom shouted. The call went echoing down the empty aisles and died out in the distance in a faint sound that resembled a ripple of mocking laughter.  

"Oh, don't do it again, Tom, it is too horrid," said Becky.  

"It is horrid, but I better, Becky; they might hear us, you know," and he shouted again.  

The "might" was even a chillier horror than the ghostly laughter, it so confessed a perishing hope. The children stood still and listened; but there was no result. Tom turned upon the back track at once, and hurried his steps. It was but a little while before a certain indecision in his manner revealed another fearful fact to Becky—he could not find his way back!  

"Oh, Tom, you didn't make any marks!"  

"Becky, I was such a fool! Such a fool! I never thought we might want to come back! No—I can't find the way. It's all mixed up."  

"Tom, Tom, we're lost! we're lost! We never can get out of this awful place! Oh, why did we ever leave the others!"  

She sank to the ground and burst into such a frenzy of crying that Tom was appalled with the idea that she might die, or lose her reason. He sat down by her and put his arms around her; she buried her face in his bosom, she clung to him, she poured out her terrors, her unavailing regrets, and the far echoes turned them all to jeering laughter. Tom begged her to pluck up hope again, and she said she could not. He fell to blaming and abusing himself for getting her into this miserable situation; this had a better effect. She said she would try to hope again, she would get up and follow wherever he might lead if only he would not talk like that any more. For he was no more to blame than she, she said.  

*(From *The Adventures of Tom Sawyer* by Mark Twain, Chapter XXXI.)*

Every step they took seemed to deepen the mystery of the cave. The flickering light from their candles cast eerie shadows on the damp, jagged walls, making the passage feel even more ominous. Tom, usually so full of bold ideas, felt a creeping unease. Huck, walking close behind him, kept glancing over his shoulder, half-expecting to see something—or someone—lurking in the darkness.

After what felt like hours, they reached a fork in the path. Tom hesitated, then chose the left passage, hoping it would lead them back to familiar ground. But the deeper they went, the more the cave seemed to twist and turn, as if it were alive and deliberately confusing them. The air grew colder, and the silence was broken only by the occasional drip of water echoing through the tunnels.

Huck finally broke the silence. "Tom, I reckon we're lost," he whispered, his voice trembling slightly. 

Tom didn’t answer right away. He didn’t want to admit it, but he feared Huck was right. Still, he forced a grin. "Lost? Nah! We’re just takin’ the scenic route, that’s all. Ain’t every day we get to explore like this!" 

Huck wasn’t convinced. "But what if we can’t find our way back? What if we’re stuck down here forever?" 

Tom’s bravado wavered for a moment, but he quickly shook it off. "We’ll find a way out, Huck. We always do. Besides, think of the stories we’ll have to tell when we get back!" 

Huck sighed but didn’t argue further. They pressed on, their footsteps echoing in the hollow silence. The walls seemed to close in around them, and the darkness beyond their candlelight felt endless. 

Then, suddenly, Tom stopped. "Listen," he said, holding up a hand. 

Huck strained his ears. At first, he heard nothing. Then, faintly, the sound of running water reached them. 

Tom’s face lit up. "That’s the underground river! If we follow it, it might lead us out!" 

With renewed hope, they hurried toward the sound. The passage sloped downward, and soon they found themselves standing at the edge of a swift, dark stream. The water glinted in the candlelight as it rushed past, disappearing into the unknown depths of the cave. 

Tom knelt and dipped his fingers into the icy water. "This has to go somewhere. Maybe even outside!" 

Huck looked doubtful. "Or maybe it just goes deeper into the cave. We don’t know, Tom." 

Tom stood, wiping his hand on his pants. "Only one way to find out. We’ll follow it downstream. Water’s gotta go somewhere, right?" 

Huck hesitated, but he knew they had no better option. "Alright," he muttered. "But if we end up worse off, I’m blamin’ you." 

Tom chuckled, though his laughter sounded hollow in the vast emptiness of the cave. "Deal." 

Side by side, they began walking along the riverbank, their candles casting flickering light on the rushing water. The cave seemed to stretch on forever, but for the first time since they’d gotten lost, they felt a glimmer of hope. Somewhere ahead, there had to be a way out. 

And if there wasn’t? Tom pushed the thought away. They’d cross that bridge when they came to it. For now, they had to keep moving.

events.title: Conserving Resources, Battling Fatigue, and a Dream of Escape
detailed_summary: They resumed their journey, moving aimlessly and at random, driven solely by the instinct to keep moving.
Hope made a brief, unreasoned resurgence, characteristic of youth unfamiliar with repeated failure.
After some time, Tom took Becky's candle and extinguished it, an act of economy that wordlessly conveyed the gravity of their situation.
Becky understood the implication, and her hope vanished once more; she knew Tom possessed a whole candle and several pieces, making his conservation efforts deeply alarming.

Fatigue began to take its toll, yet the children resisted stopping, knowing that sitting down felt like inviting death when time was so critical and movement, in any direction, offered a sliver of hope for progress.
Eventually, Becky's legs could carry her no further, and she sat down.
Tom rested with her, and they spoke of home, friends, the comfort of their beds, and most acutely, the light.
Becky cried, and Tom found his usual encouragements had become worn and sounded sarcastic.
Exhaustion overwhelmed Becky, and she drifted off to sleep, for which Tom was grateful.
He watched her drawn face soften and appear natural under the influence of pleasant dreams, and a smile eventually graced her lips.
Her peaceful expression brought a measure of peace to his own spirit, and his thoughts wandered to past times and dreamlike memories.
While Tom was lost in his thoughts, Becky awoke with a lighthearted laugh, which instantly died on her lips, followed by a groan.
She lamented having slept and wished she hadn't woken, then quickly recanted, not wanting to upset Tom.
Tom reassured her that sleep was beneficial and that they would find their way out.
Becky agreed they could try, but mentioned a beautiful country she had seen in her dream, implying a premonition of death and a journey to an afterlife.

events.text_segment:
So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving. For a little while, hope made a show of reviving—not with any reason to back it, but only because it is its nature to revive when the spring has not been taken out of it by age and familiarity with failure.
By-and-by Tom took Becky’s candle and blew it out. This economy meant so much! Words were not needed. Becky understood, and her hope died again. She knew that Tom had a whole candle and three or four pieces in his pockets—yet he must economize.
By-and-by, fatigue began to assert its claims; the children tried to pay attention, for it was dreadful to think of sitting down when time was grown to be so precious, moving, in some direction, in any direction, was at least progress and might bear fruit; but to sit down was to invite death and shorten its pursuit.
At last Becky’s frail limbs refused to carry her farther. She sat down. Tom rested with her, and they talked of home, and the friends there, and the comfortable beds and, above all, the light! Becky cried, and Tom tried to think of some way of comforting her, but all his encouragements were grown thread-bare with use, and sounded like sarcasms. Fatigue bore so heavily upon Becky that she drowsed off to sleep. Tom was grateful. He sat looking into her drawn face and saw it grow smooth and natural under the influence of pleasant dreams; and by-and-by a smile dawned and rested there. The peaceful face reflected somewhat of peace and healing into his own spirit, and his thoughts wandered away to bygone times and dreamy memories. While he was deep in his musings, Becky woke up with a breezy little laugh—but it was stricken dead upon her lips, and a groan followed it.
“Oh, how could I sleep! I wish I never, never had waked! No! No, I don’t, Tom! Don’t look so! I won’t say it again.”
“I’m glad you’ve slept, Becky; you’ll feel rested, now, and we’ll find the way out.”
“We can try, Tom; but I’ve seen such a beautiful country in my dream. I reckon we are going there.”

So they moved on again—aimlessly—simply at random—all they could do was to move, keep moving. The dense woods swallowed them whole, the towering trees casting long shadows that seemed to stretch endlessly before them. Tom led the way, his heart pounding with a mix of fear and exhilaration, while Huck and Joe followed close behind, their footsteps muffled by the thick carpet of fallen leaves.  

The sun dipped lower in the sky, painting the forest in hues of gold and amber, but the boys paid little heed to its beauty. Hunger gnawed at their stomachs, and their earlier bravado had faded into weary silence. Every rustle of leaves, every distant birdcall, sent shivers down their spines. The wilderness, once a playground for their adventures, now felt vast and unforgiving.  

Tom clutched the piece of chalk in his pocket, the same one he had used to mark their path on the cave walls. But here, in the open woods, there were no walls to mark—only endless trees and the creeping dread of being lost forever. He glanced back at his companions, their faces streaked with dirt and exhaustion.  

"We gotta find shelter before dark," Tom muttered, more to himself than to the others.  

Huck nodded grimly, his usual carefree grin long gone. "Ain't no use wanderin' in circles," he said. "We might as well pick a direction and stick to it."  

Joe Harper, usually the most spirited of the three, merely sighed and wiped his brow. "I just wanna sit down," he admitted.  

But Tom knew stopping wasn’t an option. Nightfall would bring colder air, wild animals, and who knew what else. So they pressed on, their feet dragging, their spirits sinking with each step. The forest seemed to mock them, its paths twisting and turning in ways that defied logic.  

And yet, somewhere deep inside, Tom couldn’t help but feel a thrill. This was real adventure—no rules, no grown-ups, just the wild unknown. If only they weren’t so hungry. If only they weren’t so lost.  

The shadows grew longer. The air grew colder. And still, they moved.

events.title: The Last of the Food and the Final Candle's Grim Revelation
detailed_summary: Tom tried to encourage Becky, urging her to remain hopeful and continue their efforts.

They walked onward, hand in hand, feeling utterly hopeless, with no accurate sense of how long they had been trapped, though it seemed like days or weeks; however, the fact their candles were not yet fully consumed indicated this perception was skewed.
After a considerable, unquantifiable time, Tom suggested they move quietly and listen for the sound of dripping water, hoping to find a spring.
They soon located one, and Tom declared it was time to rest again.
Although both were severely tired, Becky felt she could continue a bit longer and was surprised when Tom disagreed, unable to understand his reasoning.
They sat down, and Tom used some clay to affix his candle to the wall before them.
A period of silent thought passed before Becky broke the silence, stating her hunger.
Tom retrieved something from his pocket.
He asked if she remembered it.
A faint smile touched Becky's lips as she recognized it as their 'wedding-cake' from the picnic.
Tom expressed a wish for it to be much larger, as it was all the food they possessed.
Becky explained she had saved it for them to dream on, as adults do with wedding cake, but her sentence trailed off, hinting at a grim alternative outcome.
Tom divided the cake; Becky ate her portion with a good appetite, while Tom only nibbled at his share.
They had ample cold water from the spring to accompany their meager meal.
After a while, Becky suggested they move on again.
Tom remained silent for a moment before speaking.
He asked Becky if she could bear to hear something important.
Becky's face paled, but she indicated she could.
Tom then revealed the grim necessity: they had to remain where they were, near the water source, because the small piece of candle currently burning was their very last.
Becky succumbed to tears and wailing, and Tom's attempts to console her had little success.
Eventually, Becky voiced a flicker of hope, suggesting they would be missed and searched for.
Tom eagerly agreed.
They speculated that the search might already be underway.
They discussed when their absence might be noticed, guessing it would be when the picnic group returned to the boat.
Becky worried it might be dark by then, questioning if their absence would be noted.
Tom was unsure but suggested Becky's mother would miss her as soon as the family returned home.
A look of fright on Becky's face made Tom realize his error: Becky wasn't expected home that night.
The children fell into a somber, thoughtful silence.

“Maybe not, maybe not. Cheer up, Becky, and let’s go on trying.”
They rose up and wandered along, hand in hand and hopeless. They tried to estimate how long they had been in the cave, but all they knew was that it seemed days and weeks, and yet it was plain that this could not be, for their candles were not gone yet. A long time after this—they could not tell how long—Tom said they must go softly and listen for dripping water—they must find a spring. They found one presently, and Tom said it was time to rest again. Both were cruelly tired, yet Becky said she thought she could go a little farther. She was surprised to hear Tom dissent. She could not understand it. They sat down, and Tom fastened his candle to the wall in front of them with some clay. Thought was soon busy; nothing was said for some time. Then Becky broke the silence:
“Tom, I am so hungry!”
Tom took something out of his pocket.
“Do you remember this?” said he.
Becky almost smiled.
“It’s our wedding-cake, Tom.”
“Yes—I wish it was as big as a barrel, for it’s all we’ve got.”
“I saved it from the picnic for us to dream on, Tom, the way grownup people do with wedding-cake—but it’ll be our—”
She dropped the sentence where it was. Tom divided the cake and Becky ate with good appetite, while Tom nibbled at his moiety. There was abundance of cold water to finish the feast with. By-and-by Becky suggested that they move on again. Tom was silent a moment. Then he said:
“Becky, can you bear it if I tell you something?”
Becky’s face paled, but she thought she could.
“Well, then, Becky, we must stay here, where there’s water to drink. That little piece is our last candle!”
Becky gave loose to tears and wailings. Tom did what he could to comfort her, but with little effect. At length Becky said:
“Tom!”
“Well, Becky?”
“They’ll miss us and hunt for us!”
“Yes, they will! Certainly they will!”
“Maybe they’re hunting for us now, Tom.”
“Why, I reckon maybe they are. I hope they are.”
“When would they miss us, Tom?”
“When they get back to the boat, I reckon.”
“Tom, it might be dark then—would they notice we hadn’t come?”
“I don’t know. But anyway, your mother would miss you as soon as they got home.”
A frightened look in Becky’s face brought Tom to his senses and he saw that he had made a blunder. Becky was not to have gone home that night! The children became silent and thoughtful.

events.title: Into Darkness, Fleeting Hope, and Crushing Disappointment
detailed_summary: A fresh outburst of grief from Becky quickly showed Tom that she, too, had grasped the dreadful implication: Mrs. Thatcher might not realize Becky was missing until Sunday morning was well underway.
The children fixated on their tiny piece of candle, watching it melt away slowly and relentlessly.

They saw the half-inch of wick stand alone, observed the feeble flame rise and fall, climb the column of smoke, hover at its peak, and then extinguish, plunging them into absolute, horrifying darkness.
Neither Tom nor Becky could tell how much time passed before Becky became dimly aware that she was crying in Tom's arms.
All they knew was that after what felt like an immense duration, both emerged from a deep, sleep-like stupor, only to resume their suffering.
Tom speculated it might now be Sunday, or possibly Monday.
He attempted to get Becky to talk, but her sorrows were too overwhelming, and all her hope had vanished.
Tom insisted they must have been missed long ago and that a search was undoubtedly in progress.
He decided to shout, hoping someone might come.
He tried, but in the total darkness, the distant echoes sounded so terrifyingly hideous that he refrained from trying again.
The hours passed, and hunger began to afflict the captives once more.
A portion of Tom's half of the cake remained; they divided and consumed it.
However, they seemed even hungrier than before, the small morsel of food only serving to sharpen their desire.
After some time, Tom suddenly urged Becky to be quiet, asking if she heard something.
Both held their breath and listened intently, detecting a sound like the faintest, most distant shout.
Tom instantly responded to it and, taking Becky's hand, began to grope his way down the corridor in the direction of the sound.
He listened again; the sound was repeated, seemingly a little closer.
Tom exclaimed that it was 'them,' their rescuers, and urged Becky along, declaring they were now all right.
The prisoners' joy was nearly overpowering.
Their progress was slow, however, as pitfalls were relatively common and required caution.
They soon reached one such chasm and were forced to stop; it could have been three feet deep or a hundred, but regardless, it was impassable.
Tom lay on his stomach and reached down as far as he could but found no bottom, meaning they had to stay put and wait for the searchers.
They listened, only to realize with sinking hearts that the distant shouts were growing fainter.
A moment or two later, the sounds had vanished completely, bringing an overwhelming sense of misery.
Tom shouted until he was hoarse, but it was futile.
He spoke with forced hopefulness to Becky, but an agonizingly long period of anxious waiting passed with no further sounds.

events.title: A Desperate Exploration and a Terrifying Encounter
detailed_summary: The children groped their way back to the spring.
The weary time continued to pass; they slept again and awoke famished and filled with woe.
Tom now believed it must be Tuesday.
An idea occurred to him: exploring some of the nearby side passages would be preferable to enduring the heavy passage of time in idleness.
He retrieved a kite-line from his pocket, secured it to a rock projection, and he and Becky set off, with Tom leading and unwinding the line as he navigated.
After about twenty steps, the corridor terminated at a 'jumping-off place,' a sudden drop.
Tom got on his knees, felt below, and then extended his hands as far as he could around a corner to his right.
As he stretched a little further, a human hand holding a candle appeared from behind a rock, not twenty yards away.
Tom let out a glorious shout, believing it to be a rescuer.
Instantly, the hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe.
Tom was paralyzed with terror and could not move.
The next moment, he felt immense relief as he saw the 'Spaniard' (Injun Joe in disguise) turn and flee out of sight.
Tom was puzzled that Joe hadn't recognized his voice and come to kill him for his testimony in court.
He reasoned that the cave's echoes must have disguised his voice, believing this was undoubtedly the explanation.
The fright left Tom's muscles weak; he told himself that if he could muster the strength to return to the spring, he would stay there and avoid any risk of another encounter with Injun Joe.
He was careful to keep what he had seen a secret from Becky, telling her he had merely shouted 'for luck.'

The children groped their way back to the spring. The weary time dragged on; they slept again, and awoke famished and woe-stricken. Tom believed it must be Tuesday by this time.
Now an idea struck him. There were some side passages near at hand. It would be better to explore some of these than bear the weight of the heavy time in idleness. He took a kite-line from his pocket, tied it to a projection, and he and Becky started, Tom in the lead, unwinding the line as he groped along. At the end of twenty steps the corridor ended in a “jumping-off place.” Tom got down on his knees and felt below, and then as far around the corner as he could reach with his hands conveniently; he made an effort to stretch yet a little farther to the right, and at that moment, not twenty yards away, a human hand, holding a candle, appeared from behind a rock! Tom lifted up a glorious shout, and instantly that hand was followed by the body it belonged to—Injun Joe’s! Tom was paralyzed; he could not move. He was vastly gratified the next moment, to see the “Spaniard” take to his heels and get himself out of sight. Tom wondered that Joe had not recognized his voice and come over and killed him for testifying in court. But the echoes must have disguised the voice. Without doubt, that was it, he reasoned. Tom’s fright weakened every muscle in his body. He said to himself that if he had strength enough to get back to the spring he would stay there, and nothing should tempt him to run the risk of meeting Injun Joe again. He was careful to keep from Becky what it was he had seen. He told her he had only shouted “for luck.”

detailed_summary: In the dead of night, the village church bells rang out frantically, signaling the children's discovery.
The streets quickly filled with ecstatic, partially clothed residents shouting that Tom and Becky were found.
The celebratory noise escalated with the addition of tin pans and horns as the townsfolk converged and headed towards the river.
They encountered the children arriving in an open carriage, drawn by cheering citizens, and a massive, jubilant procession escorted them up the main street with continuous huzzahs.
The entire village was lit up, and normal routines were abandoned in what became the most memorable night in the town's history.

For the first thirty minutes after their return, a stream of villagers passed through Judge Thatcher's home, emotionally greeting the rescued children, offering comfort to Mrs. Thatcher, and departing overwhelmed with tears of joy.

It would be complete, however, as soon as the messenger dispatched with the great news to the cave should get the word to her husband. Tom lay upon a sofa with an eager auditory about him and told the history of the wonderful adventure, putting in many striking additions to adorn it withal; and closed with a description of how he left Becky and went on an exploring expedition; how he followed two avenues as far as his kite-line would reach; how he followed a third to the fullest stretch of the kite-line, and was about to turn back when he glimpsed a far-off speck that looked like daylight; dropped the line and groped toward it, pushed his head and shoulders through a small hole, and saw the broad Mississippi rolling by!
And if it had only happened to be night he would not have seen that speck of daylight and would not have explored that passage any more! He told how he went back for Becky and broke the good news and she told him not to fret her with such stuff, for she was tired, and knew she was going to die, and wanted to. He described how he labored with her and convinced her; and how she almost died for joy when she had groped to where she actually saw the blue speck of daylight; how he pushed his way out at the hole and then helped her out; how they sat there and cried for gladness; how some men came along in a skiff and Tom hailed them and told them their situation and their famished condition; how the men didn’t believe the wild tale at first, “because,” said they, “you are five miles down the river below the valley the cave is in”—then took them aboard, rowed to a house, gave them supper, made them rest till two or three hours after dark and then brought them home.
Before day-dawn, Judge Thatcher and the handful of searchers with him were tracked out, in the cave, by the twine clews they had strung behind them, and informed of the great news.
